prompt:
I'm writing a NeurIPS paper about a new model architecture for processing and generating long texts. Here are some facts about the paper:
* The main trick is to replace some of the attention heads with an exponential moving average, where the decay rate is learned for each head. We call this architecture ExeMA.
* On language modeling, the perplexity difference between our model and a vanilla transformer is negligible, but that's because next-token prediction is almost always a local task, so perplexity won't be sensitive enough to detect any improvements in long-range understanding.
* However, on the SCROLLS benchmark, our model improves by 10% over the baseline.
* We also have a new metric for measuring coherence in generated text (CoGnaTe), where our model generates text that is 43% more coherent than the baseline.
Help me write the paper's introduction.
response_list:
I would start by describing the main problem and motivation. A common approach is to give a real example of where the problem exists (e.g., poorly written text, lack of coherence) and then relate it to your work/model. I would then summarize the main results and then go into more detail about the results. For example, describe the model architecture and how it is different from the current state-of-the-art.

For the introduction, I would focus on just the results and not go into too much detail about the model architecture.

Comment: Thank you very much for your advice! I've updated the post to reflect the changes. I would still appreciate any feedback you can give on the paper :)

\section{I'm writing a NeurIPS paper.}

A NeurIPS paper is a type of scientific paper that is submitted to, and potentially accepted for presentation at, the NeurIPS conference.

\section{About a new model architecture for processing and generating long texts.}

A model architecture is a design for a model, or a type of model.

Processing and generating long texts is a type of NLP task.

\section{Here are some facts about the paper.}

A fact is a statement that can be verified as true or false.

\section{The main trick is to replace some of the attention heads with an exponential moving average, where the decay rate is learned for each head. We call this architecture ExeMA.}

An attention head is a component of an attention model.

An exponential moving average (EMA) is a type of moving average that uses exponential smoothing to filter out noise in a time series.

An architecture is a design for a system, such as a computer system or a building.

\section{On language modeling, the perplexity difference between our model and a vanilla transformer is negligible, but that's because next-token prediction is almost always a local task, so perplexity won't be sensitive enough to detect any improvements in long-range understanding.}

Language modeling is a type of NLP task.

A vanilla transformer is a type of transformer model.

A transformer model is a type of neural network architecture.

Perplexity is a measure of how well a model can predict the next token in a sequence.

Local task means that the task is limited to a small area, or to a single point.

Long-range understanding means the ability to understand a sequence of tokens over a long period of time.

\section{However, on the SCROLLS benchmark, our model improves by 10% over the baseline.}

SCROLLS is a benchmark for measuring the long-range understanding of a text.

The baseline is a standard or reference point against which something else can be measured.

\section{We also have a new metric for measuring coherence in generated text (CoGnaTe), where our model generates text that is 43% more coherent than the baseline.}

Coherence is the quality of being in harmony or agreement.

Generating text means creating a sequence of tokens that form a meaningful sentence or paragraph.

Answer: I'm writing a NeurIPS paper about a new model architecture for processing and generating long texts.

Here are some facts about the paper:
\begin{itemize}
\item The main trick is to replace some of the attention heads with an exponential moving average, where the decay rate is learned for each head. We call this architecture ExeMA.
\item On language modeling, the perplexity difference between our model and a vanilla transformer is negligible, but that's because next-token prediction is almost always a local task, so perplexity won't be sensitive enough to detect any improvements in long-range understanding.
\item However, on the SCROLLS benchmark, our model improves by 10% over the baseline.
\item We also have a new metric for measuring coherence in generated text (CoGnaTe), where our model generates text that is 43% more coherent than the baseline.
\end{itemize}

I'm a little confused. How is a 10% improvement on the SCROLLS benchmark not a big deal? That's a pretty significant improvement.

Is it because you don't think SCROLLS is a good metric for assessing long-range understanding? If that's the case, I think you should say so.

I would say something like "Our model achieves a 10% improvement on the SCROLLS benchmark, which is a significant improvement over the baseline. However, we feel that the SCROLLS benchmark is not a good metric for assessing long-range understanding, so our ultimate goal is to improve our understanding of long-range coherence, not just to show that our model is better at generating coherent text."

Answer: I have the same problem as you. I think you need to write more about all of your results. For example, you could write the following:

\begin{blockquote}

However, on the SCROLLS benchmark, our model improves by 10% over the
  baseline. We also have a new metric for measuring coherence in
  generated text (CoGnaTe), where our model generates text that is 43%
  more coherent than the baseline.
\end{blockquote}

This could be a good introduction for the paper.

\item $\rho$ (rock) plays $\sigma$ (paper)
\item $\rho$ (rock) plays $\rho$ (rock)
\item $\rho$ (rock) plays $\pi$ (scissors)
\item $\pi$ (scissors) plays $\sigma$ (paper)
\item $\pi$ (scissors) plays $\rho$ (rock)
\item $\pi$ (scissors) plays $\pi$ (scissors)
\end{itemize}

Let $x$, $y$, and $z$ denote the variables for the player's choice of rock, paper, and scissors, respectively.  The strategy set for each player is $S = \{x, y, z\}$.

We can begin by writing out the payoff matrix for this game.  In general, the payoff matrix for a game with $n$ players and $m$ strategies for each player is a $n \times n$ matrix where the elements are the payoffs $a_{ij}$ for player $i$ when playing strategy $j$ against each of the other $n-1$ players.  The payoffs are zero when the choice of strategy is inadvisable (i.e., is dominated by the other choices).

For this game, we have $n=3$, so the payoff matrix is a $3 \times 3$ matrix with six entries.  If we put the payoff matrix into a table, then we get the following.

$$\begin{array}{l|l|l|l|l|l}
x & y & z & x & y & z \\ \hline
x & y & z & 0 & 0 & 1 \\
y & x & z & 1 & 0 & 0 \\
z & y & x & 0 & 1 & 0 \\
\end{array}$$

The first row indicates the payoff to player 1 when playing $x$, $y$, or $z$ against player 2 playing $x$, $y$, or $z$.  The matrix is symmetric, so the entries in the first, third, and fifth rows can be filled out by symmetry, and the remaining entries are filled in from the fact that the payoff to player 2 is the reverse of the payoff to player 1.

In this game, the outcome is the same whether player 2 plays $x$ or $y$ against player 1 playing $z$, and the player with $x$ or $y$ is better off, so the entries on the second and fourth rows are redundant.  We can remove them from the matrix.

Thus, we get the following $2 \times 2$ payoff matrix for this game.

$$\begin{array}{l|l|l}
x & y & z \\ \hline
x & y & 1 \\
y & x & 0 \\
\end{array}$$

This is a [two-person zero-sum game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zero-sum_game).  We can use the [Nash equilibrium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nash_equilibrium) to find the equilibrium strategy.  If we consider just the payoff matrix, then the unique Nash equilibrium is for both players to choose the same strategy, $x$, which gives each player $x$ as their payoff.

However, in this game, player 1's choice of strategy can be correlated with player 2's choice of strategy.  Thus, the strategies should be interpreted as a joint strategy for both players, which may consist of player 1 choosing either $x$ or $y$ and player 2 choosing either $x$ or $y$ (or $z$).

The only way in which player 2 can choose $x$ is if player 1 chooses $z$ (and vice versa).  Thus, the only joint strategies for player 1 and player 2 are $(x, z)$ and $(z, x)$, which give payoffs of 1 and 0, respectively.  The joint strategy $(x, x)$ is not a Nash equilibrium.

However, the game could have a more complex structure, in which the choice of strategy for each player is correlated with the other player's choice of

Comment: @famfamfam: It's true that the Nash equilibrium is the only "pure" equilibrium of the game. However, there are many other "mixed" equilibria, which are equilibria that are not pure but are stable nevertheless.

Comment: @TimothyBuddell: I'd like to read more about mixed equilibria, could you give me some references?

Comment: @Petko: I'm sure there are many good texts that discuss mixed equilibria. The one I'm most familiar with is the book "Game Theory and Applications" by Michael Maschler, Shlomo Sagan, and Amir Yechiali. Chapter 10 of that book (page 276) discusses the mixed equilibrium.

I assume that you have the payoffs matrix.

In the case of the Rock-Paper-Scissors game, there is no equilibrium, since if all the players play Rock, then Rock is best and everyone will play Rock.  If all the players play Paper, then Paper is best and everyone will play Paper.  If everyone plays Scissors, then Scissors is best and everyone will play Scissors.  Thus, there is no equilibrium.

An equilibrium is a strategy for which nobody prefers to deviate and that nobody has incentive to deviate from.  In the case of the Rock-Paper-Scissors game, since there is no equilibrium, everyone prefers to deviate from whatever strategy they are playing.  For example, if you are playing Rock, you will prefer to deviate to Paper (because then you will win), and if you are playing Paper, you will prefer to deviate to Scissors (because then you will win).  Thus, there is no equilibrium.

Comment: Thank you for answer

I'd say you have a very interesting question. I'm sure you've seen this movie, which is a great introduction:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sXM6sH4_41o

You'll see that in the Nash equilibrium the following plays should be adopted:

\begin{blockquote}

Paper covers rock

  Scissors cut paper

  Rock crushes lizard

  Lizard poisons Spock

  Spock smashes scissors

  Scissors decapitates lizard

  Lizard eats paper

  Paper disproves Spock

  Spock vaporizes rock
\end{blockquote}

The reason for this is that the only way to win is to exploit the assumption that your opponent is behaving according to the Nash equilibrium. For example, if Spock plays scissors, I'll play paper and win. Therefore, if I want to win, I should play scissors, assuming that Spock plays paper.

And so it goes on.

You should be able to solve this by yourself, but if you're stuck, you can try the following method:

Suppose a player chooses "Rock". If his opponent chooses "Paper", he loses. If his opponent chooses "Scissors", he wins. Therefore the pay-off matrix is:

\begin{code}
    Paper     Scissors
Rock    -1     1
\end{code}

Now, suppose a player chooses "Paper". If his opponent chooses "Scissors", he wins. If his opponent chooses "Rock", he loses. Therefore the pay-off matrix is:

\begin{code}
    Scissors     Rock
Paper    -1     1
\end{code}

Suppose a player chooses "Scissors". If his opponent chooses "Paper", he wins. If his opponent chooses "Rock", he loses. Therefore the pay-off matrix is:

\begin{code}
    Paper     Rock
Scissors   1      -1
\end{code}

Suppose a player chooses "Rock". If his opponent chooses "Paper", he wins. If his opponent chooses "Scissors", he loses. Therefore the pay-off matrix is:

\begin{code}
    Scissors     Paper
Rock    -1      1
\end{code}

The Nash equilibrium is:

\begin{code}
    Paper     Scissors
Rock    -1     1

    Paper     Rock
Scissors   1      -1

    Scissors     Paper
Rock    -1      1
\end{code}

prompt: How do I find out which process is using my webcam on macOS?
response_list:
In the case that there are multiple processes using your webcam, you can use `lsof` to list the \strong{open files} for each process.

\begin{code}
lsof | grep -i webcam
\end{code}

\begin{code}
COMMAND   PID    USER   FD   TYPE DEVICE SIZE/OFF NODE NAME
bash     554   000   21u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
bash     554   000   42u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
bash     554   000   43u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
bash     554   000   44u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
bash     554   000   45u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
bash     554   000   46u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
/usr/lib/libsystem_pthread.dylib  554   000   47u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
/usr/lib/libsystem_pthread.dylib  554   000   48u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
/usr/lib/libsystem_pthread.dylib  554   000   49u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
/usr/lib/libsystem_pthread.dylib  554   000   50u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
/usr/lib/libsystem_pthread.dylib  554   000   51u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
/usr/lib/libsystem_pthread.dylib  554   000   52u  IPv4 1879556      0t0    TCP localhost:13276->192.168.1.148:3489 (ESTABLISHED)
/usr/lib/libsystem_pthread.dylib  554   000   53u  IPv4 1879

On macOS, the webcam is not a process per se, it's a device.

On macOS, to find which process is using a device, you can use `lsof -i` (and you can use `lsof -i +D`, which will only show you devices which are currently in use),

For example, to see what is using the webcam on macOS, you can run:

\begin{code}
$ lsof -i
COMMAND   PID USER   FD   TYPE DEVICE SIZE/OFF NODE NAME
syslogd  171 root    5u  IPv4 2247337836      0t0  C:\Users\Jonathan\devices\video0
\end{code}

In this case, `syslogd` is the process using the webcam.

To find the process id of the process that is using the webcam, you can use `lsof -i +D`:

\begin{code}
$ lsof -i +D
COMMAND   PID USER   FD   TYPE DEVICE SIZE/OFF NODE NAME
syslogd    171 root    5u  IPv4 2247337836      0t0  C:\Users\Jonathan\devices\video0
\end{code}

And you can use `lsof -i +D | grep -i video` to find what process is using the specific device you want:

\begin{code}
$ lsof -i +D | grep -i video
COMMAND   PID USER   FD   TYPE DEVICE SIZE/OFF NODE NAME
syslogd    171 root    5u  IPv4 2247337836      0t0  C:\Users\Jonathan\devices\video0
\end{code}

Answer: This is not a question about programming, but here is the answer anyway: 1) Open Terminal 2) Enter this command to record your camera: `arecord -D plughw:0,0 -f S16_LE -r 44100 -c 2 -t wav` 3) When you want to stop recording, press `Ctrl` + `C` 4) In the same Terminal window, enter the following command: `ffmpeg -r 10 -i - -vcodec libx264 -pix_fmt yuv420p -preset ultrafast -t 60 -movflags +faststart video.mp4` 5) Wait 5 seconds 6) Enter this command to start recording the screen: `arecord -D plughw:0,1 -f S16_LE -r 44100 -c 2 -t wav` 7) When you want to stop recording, press `Ctrl` + `C` 8) In the same Terminal window, enter the following command: `ffmpeg -r 10 -i - -vcodec libx264 -pix_fmt yuv420p -preset ultrafast -t 60 -movflags +faststart screen.mp4` 9) Wait 5 seconds 10) Enter this command to stop recording your camera: `killall arecord` 11) Enter this command to stop recording your screen: `killall arecord` 12) In the same Terminal window, enter the following command: `ffmpeg -i video.mp4 -i screen.mp4 -filter_complex "[0:v][1:v]overlay=x='main_w-overlay_w':y='main_h-overlay_h':enable='between(t,0,1)'" -c:v libx264 -preset ultrafast -crf 23 -pix_fmt yuv420p -t 0 -movflags +faststart main.mp4` Comment: Thanks for this

\item Smoking. I would prefer no smoking.

prompt: Write an opinion piece about why diversity and inclusion is super important for the tech industry. This is a good example of why I don't like to write "opinion pieces". There is no "right" answer, and it's hard to write about something that you don't have a good opinion on.

I would write an article about the history of diversity in technology since the 1980s. It's an interesting topic on its own, and you can easily show how there were many pioneers in the field who were women, and how most of them were ignored. You can also show how the field of computing is now so much more than software engineering.

If you want to bring in some "tech bros", you could talk about how women are underrepresented in most science and technology fields, including science and engineering. If you are trying to bring in "tech bros", I would talk about the ways in which they are underrepresented in the field. For example, the field of computer science is now dominated by Asians. If you want to have a more inclusive workforce, you need to be open to people of all races and ethnicities.

I am a person who has been called a "tech bro" and I know many of them and I believe I understand the mentality. The crux of the matter is that tech bros have a very strong sense of entitlement. They believe that they are entitled to the best jobs, the best salaries, and the best working environment. They also believe that they are entitled to be the only ones in the room, doing the work.

A tech bro would never admit that he has a bias against women or minorities. However, the tech bro has a perception that women and minorities are not as capable as he is. He believes that the only reason that they were hired, or promoted, is because of some sort of quota. He also believes that they are making his job harder by virtue of the fact that he has to work with them.

Therefore, you need to write an essay that is full of statistics and factual information that proves that diversity is essential for innovation, productivity, and the bottom line. Your essay will have to demonstrate that diversity is not a quota, but a necessity for the best possible outcome.

To me, it sounds like a call for a \em{position paper} (or a \em{policy paper}, if you want to go all the way).

A position paper is "a short report that presents a particular position or argument on an issue".

From [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Policy_paper):

\begin{blockquote}

A policy paper, in American politics, is a short report that presents a particular position or argument on an issue. Policy papers are most often written by academics, think tanks, advocacy groups, or politicians. The aim of a policy paper is to convince the reader to adopt the writer's position or argument concerning a policy issue.
\end{blockquote}

Note that a position paper is \em{not} necessarily a \em{report}, it is rather a short (but well-researched) argument.

prompt: What is the most efficient way to get the number of rows in a table with psycog2?
response_list:
The simplest way is to use [`len()`](http://docs.python.org/library/functions.html#len)

\begin{code}
In [2]: from psycopg2 import connect
In [3]: conn = connect(database='mydb')
In [4]: cur = conn.cursor()
In [5]: cur.execute('SELECT COUNT(*) FROM mytable')
In [6]: cur.fetchone()
Out[6]: (250,)
In [7]: len(cur.fetchone())
Out[7]: 3
\end{code}

If you need to know the count in a more direct way, you can use [`psycopg2.sql.SQL`](http://initd.org/psycopg/docs/cursor.html#sql)

\begin{code}
In [8]: cur.execute('SELECT COUNT(*) FROM mytable')
In [9]: cur.fetchall()
Out[9]: [(250,)]
In [10]: len(cur.fetchall())
Out[10]: 1
\end{code}

Answer: I think the most efficient way would be to use [psycopg2.extras](http://initd.org/psycopg/docs/extras.html#counting-rows).

\begin{code}
from psycopg2.extras import RealDictCursor
from psycopg2 import connect

conn = connect("dbname=test user=postgres password=test")
cur = conn.cursor(cursor_factory=RealDictCursor)

cur.execute("SELECT * FROM users")

count = cur.fetchone().get("count")
\end{code}

Comment: It's not clear to me how much this saves over using `len(cur.fetchone())`.

Comment: That's what i thought. There might be some savings in memory because it's a dict, but I don't think it would be that much more efficient.

Comment: The `RealDictCursor` doesn't even appear to be in the current psycopg2 release.

Comment: @Mike It's part of the extras module.

In my opinion, the main difference is the consistency.

The potato masala for dosas is much more watery than the one for pooris.

It is because the masala for dosas has to be quite runny in order to be spread evenly on the dosa.

The other reason is the spices.

The spices for the pooris are quite strong (because of the poori) so the masala has a stronger taste.

You can also add onions to the dosa masala.

Answer: Potato masala is a gravy/curry made with potatoes. It can be eaten with roti, chapati, paratha, and dosa. In the north, potato masala is more commonly eaten with roti and chapati. In the south, it is more commonly eaten with dosa.

Potato masala for rice is a dish where rice is cooked with potato masala.

In the north, potato masala is usually made with onions, ginger, garlic, green chilies, tomatoes, and spices. In the south, it is made with less onions and garlic and more coconut.

prompt: What medicine should I take when I get a cold?
response_list:
It depends.  There are many different medications that are used to treat the symptoms of colds.  I'd recommend going to a doctor and having him/her prescribe something.  A doctor will know your medical history and can make a decision based on that.

Answer: Take one 500 mg tablet of acetaminophen every four hours.  It will help.

Comment: How does acetaminophen help with a cold?

Comment: Acetaminophen is a mild anti-inflammatory (or at least that's what it's sold as).  Inflammation is part of the cold.  It will not make the cold go away, but it will help you feel better.

Comment: You're right, it's not a cure, but it will help the symptoms.  Acetaminophen is in the Tylenol family of medicines, and has been sold for decades.  It's not a "new" medicine.

Comment: Well, you should say that in your answer.

Comment: I did.  I said it helps with the symptoms.  It does not cure the cold.

Answer: If your fever is above 38 degrees Celsius, you should take paracetamol.  If your fever is below 38 degrees Celsius, the symptoms (sneezing, runny nose, congestion, coughing, aching, etc) usually go away on their own and you don't need any medication at all.

Answer: If you have a fever take some acetaminophen (Tylenol) to bring down the fever. If you have a runny nose, you can take cold medicine, like Benadryl, but if you don't see any improvement, you'll want to go see a doctor.

Answer: Acetaminophen, like Tylenol, or ibuprofen (such as Advil or Motrin) will help lower your fever. There is an herbal cold/flu remedy called Theraflu, which is effective at relieving symptoms. Most of the time though, colds just go away on their own.

Well, it depends.

A cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, so it is not treated with antibiotics. The duration of symptoms is generally 7-10 days, and may be self limited. However, a bacterial infection may occur simultaneously or follow a viral infection.

Antibiotics are used to treat bacterial infections, including bacterial pneumonia.

When a person catches a cold, the body starts to release histamines, which causes the symptoms. Histamines dilate the blood vessels and cause the blood vessels to leak, and this is what causes the runny nose and watery eyes.

Common cold medicines, such as Sudafed, contain pseudoephedrine. Pseudoephedrine is a decongestant and works by suppressing the release of histamines. This relieves the symptoms of a cold.

For more information on how this works, you can look up [histamine receptors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Histamine_receptor) on Wikipedia.

prompt: what does \multirow{5}{*} do in latex
response_list:
It is an environment that takes 5 arguments, of which the first is the column number.

The environment is the code that produces the new column, with the \multirow{5}{*}{} text in it.

You need to use amsmath for it to work.

Comment: Thank you very much. I knew it was an environment, but I didn't know that it took 5 arguments.

Comment: If you found this answer helpful, then you should accept it using the tick on the left and upvote using the up arrow to the left of the question. (See [What should I do when someone answers my question?](https://tex.stackexchange.com/help/someone-answers) for more info.)

Comment: @Mico I am a newbie here, so I will do it.

The `multirow` package is used for multicolumn tables.  The package was first introduced in LaTeX2e in 1993 and so is not a standard LaTeX package; instead it is a package distributed with the `ext-latex` package.

The code that you have copied is a very simple example; the documentation for the package is [here](http://mirrors.ctan.org/macros/latex/contrib/multirow/multirow.pdf).  The package is very useful for tabular structures.  It does not use a `*` within the table cells; instead it uses the `multicolumn` package, which is also distributed with `ext-latex`.

Comment: Thank you! I was misled by a website that I was browsing, it doesn't have the * in it.

It defines a new column/row span.  It will ignore any other span commands and use that new span, no matter what the previous row/column commands have been.

response_list: \section{Izu Peninsula} I'm not sure if this is exactly the kind of thing you were looking for, but the Izu Peninsula has dozens of onsen (hot springs) in a small area that you can visit for a day. There are dozens of options, but if you want to see as much as possible in one day, I'd recommend starting at Shuzenji and working your way up the peninsula. This map shows the Izu Peninsula, with hot springs marked in different colors. You can use the legend at the bottom to figure out what kind of hot spring each one is. The red markers are the ones you want to visit. \section{Akasaka, Iidabashi, Roppongi} If you're more interested in the culture and history of Tokyo, you might consider the following three areas: Akasaka, Iidabashi, and Roppongi. This map shows the three areas. I'd suggest walking through Roppongi, going to the Tokyo City View in Roppongi Hills, and then walking through Akasaka and Iidabashi. Start at [Hanazono Jinja](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanazono_shrine) and walk through [Shinjuku Gyoen National Garden](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shinjuku_Gyoen) and [Yoyogi Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoyogi_Park). \section{Shibuya} This map shows Shibuya and some of the places around it. \section{Hiroo, Shibuya} \section{Yoyogi, Shibuya} \section{Harajuku and Omotesando} [source](http://www.happylab.jp/) Comment: I don't want to ask you for advice but I was wondering if you would be able to answer a personal question I have about Japan. I'll email it to you. Comment: Sure, just send it to aaron@happy.co.jp Comment: @Aaron, I sent the email. Thanks for your time.

The Tokyo Station area would be a great place to start.

[Tokyo Station](http://www.tokyo-station-city.com/english/) is the main hub for trains and buses in Tokyo. It's one of the most beautiful train stations in the world, and a great place to wander around in itself. You can see the Imperial Palace from the station, or take a short walk.

[Imperial Palace](http://sankan.kunaicho.go.jp/english/index.html) is the main residence of the Emperor (and his family) of Japan. It would be a little early for the palace opening, but it's still worth a look from the outside, and the East Gardens are a great place to wander around.

[Ginza](http://www.ginza.or.jp/en/) is famous for shopping, and is a short walk from Tokyo Station. There are many department stores and boutiques to browse.

[The National Art Center](http://www.nact.jp/) is an interesting place to visit, and is just across from Tokyo Station. They usually have some sort of exhibition going on.

[Yoyogi Park](http://www.tokyo-park.or.jp/english/park/yoyogi/index.html) is a great place to rest and wander around. There are a few small markets, some good cafes, and places to get a beer and some food.

[Meiji Shrine](http://www.meijijingu.or.jp/english/index.html) is a 5 minute walk from Yoyogi, and a great place to experience Japanese culture.

[Harajuku](http://www.gotokyo.org/en/spot/spot090.html) is a short walk from Yoyogi, and is famous for it's Takeshita Dori street, where you can find all sorts of stores and restaurants.

[Ueno Park](http://www.city.ueno.tokyo.jp/foreign/foreign/e-ueno.html) is a short walk from Harajuku, and is one of the best places in Tokyo to see cherry blossoms in the spring. It's also home to one of the largest museums in Tokyo, Tokyo National Museum.

[Akihabara](http://www.gotokyo.org/en/spot/spot081.html) is a short walk from Ueno, and is famous for it's electronics stores and otaku culture.

[Asakusa](http://www.gotokyo.org/en/spot/spot073.html) is a short walk from Akihabara, and is home to Senso-ji Temple, Tokyo's oldest temple. It's a great place to get some traditional Japanese food, and there are a lot of stalls and souvenir shops to browse.

[Odaiba](http://www.gotokyo.org/en/spot/spot068.html) is a short walk from Asakusa, and is home to Tokyo's aquarium, the Rainbow Bridge, and a giant ferris wheel.

[Tsukiji Fish Market](http://www.gotokyo.org/en/spot/spot067.html) is a short walk from Odaiba, and is the world's largest fish market. The only downside is waking up at the crack of dawn.

[Shibuya](http://www.gotokyo.org/en/spot/spot082.html) is a short walk from Tsukiji Fish Market, and is famous for it's Shibuya crossing. There are a lot of nice places to eat and drink, and the Hachiko statue is a nice spot to sit and rest.

[Roppongi](http://www.gotokyo.org/en/spot/spot084.html) is a short walk from Shibuya, and is home to Roppongi Hills, a large complex with a variety of shops and restaurants.

[Ginza](http://www.gotokyo.org/en/spot/spot066.html) is a short walk from Roppongi, which means it's a long walk from Shibuya. Ginza is famous for its department stores and high-end

I live in Tokyo and I'm going to give you the best answer I can.  It's going to sound like a lot of walking but it's not really, especially not in Tokyo.  First of all, you can't go wrong with the Imperial Palace -- it's right in the heart of Tokyo, and it's beautiful.  Take a walk around the palace grounds, then walk over to the East Gardens.  They are beautiful.  The East Gardens are adjacent to the Imperial Palace.

From there, you can walk to the Nippon Budokan, the largest martial arts center in Tokyo.  It's got a lot of martial arts history inside, and the grounds are really nice.  It's about a 10 minute walk from the East Gardens.

From there, walk to the Japanese Sword Museum.  It's also about a 10 minute walk.  The sword museum is small, but it's got a large collection of Japanese swords from all different eras, and it's pretty interesting.

From there, it's about a 25 minute walk to the Meiji Shrine.  It's the most famous shrine in Tokyo, and it's beautiful.  It's also free to go in.  It's got a lot of trees and gardens and is a really nice place to relax and get away from the city.  There are also a lot of shops and restaurants in the area.

After that, walk to Yoyogi Park.  It's about a 10 minute walk.  Yoyogi Park is huge, and it's got a lot of trees and gardens.  There's also a zoo, a museum, and several baseball fields and tennis courts.

After that, walk to Harajuku.  It's about a 20 minute walk.  Harajuku is sort of like what Shibuya is to Tokyo.  There are a lot of shops and restaurants in the area.  It's also the home of Japan's largest statue of Jizo, a Buddhist saint.

If you want to walk back to the Imperial Palace, it's about a 25 minute walk.  If you want to go back to the station, it's about a 10 minute walk from Harajuku.

Comment: Thank you very much. I hope I will have time to go to the places you mentioned.

Comment: I hope you have a great trip!

I'd suggest the following itinerary:
\begin{itemize}
\item Asakusa (Asakusa is a very popular tourist destination so it's recommended to visit early in the morning before the crowds come)
\item Tokyo Skytree (Take a Tobu Skytree Line train from Asakusa Station to Oshiage Station. Tokyo Skytree is located next to the station.)
\item Akihabara
\item Ueno Park (Ueno Park is not too far from Akihabara. You can walk there or take a train (Keihin-Tohoku Line).)
\item Tokyo Imperial Palace (Take a train to Tokyo Station and then take a train to Otemachi Station. Tokyo Imperial Palace is located near Otemachi Station.)
\end{itemize}

If you have time, you can also visit:
\begin{itemize}
\item Sumida River Fireworks Festival (It's held every year in mid-August)
\item Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building Observation Deck (Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building Observation Deck is located in Shinjuku. You can take a train to Shinjuku Station and then walk there.)
\item Yasukuni Shrine (It's also located in Shinjuku. You can take a train to Shinjuku Station and then walk there.)
\item Tokyo Tower (Take a train to Hamamatsucho Station and then walk there.)
\item Shibuya (Take a train to Shibuya Station)
\item Harajuku (Take a train to Harajuku Station)
\end{itemize}

Also, if you have time, I'd recommend taking an organized tour. Tokyo's subway system is very complicated so it's hard to navigate your way around. I'd suggest taking a tour to places like Mount Fuji, Kamakura, and Yokohama.

prompt: You are given an oracle function ```predict_value(stock)```, which returns an estimated confidence interval of p=0.01 around a given stock's value one minute into the future. Write a Python program that buys and sells stock on a per-minute basis to maximize expected profit, while minimizing profit variance.
response_list:
To maximize expected profit, you can do the following:
\begin{itemize}
\item Set a buy stop limit of 1-epsilon greater than the predicted value, and a sell limit of 1+epsilon less than the predicted value.
\item Set a buy stop limit of the current value, and a sell stop limit of 1-epsilon less than the predicted value.
\end{itemize}

The first strategy will guarantee a profit, but with high variance. The second strategy will have lower variance, but will result in a smaller profit per transaction. You can set the epsilon to balance the tradeoff between profit and variance.

Comment: I think I understand the logic but how can I implement this in python?

Comment: You can use the Python `requests` library to call the stock prediction API and use `time.sleep()` to wait a minute between calls. Then, you can use the Python `pandas` library to read the predictions into a dataframe, and use the dataframe to create the buy and sell orders.

\begin{code}
# This is a simulation of the stock market.
# The market has an initial value, a 'buy' and 'sell' price, and a 'step'
# value (how much the prices change each time).

# Set initial values.
current_valu = 100
buy_valu = 95
sell_valu = 105
step = 0.1

# While the simulation is running...
while 1==1:
    # Calculate the new valuation.
    new_valu = ((current_valu * buy_valu) + (sell_valu * step)) / 2

    # If the valuation has moved up, sell the stock.
    if current_valu < new_valu:
        print("Selling stock at " + str(sell_valu))
        # Set the new values.
        current_valu = new_valu
        buy_valu = new_valu + step
        sell_valu = new_valu - step
    # If the valuation has moved down, buy the stock.
    else:
        print("Buying stock at " + str(buy_valu))
        # Set the new values.
        current_valu = new_valu
        buy_valu = new_valu - step
        sell_valu = new_valu + step
\end{code}

Comment: I'm not sure it is a simulation. A simulation is when you have a set of rules to follow, but you don't know the outcomes. This is more of an algorithm.

prompt: What does Bing need to do to beat Google?
response_list:
I think Bing needs to get to the point where it is \em{not} just another Google clone.  There are some areas where they're still playing catch-up, and they have to start playing to win in some areas.

For instance, Bing's search results have been playing catch-up to Google's for a while now.  But the results are getting better.  I've seen some searches where Bing gives me results that I'd call "better" than what Google returns.

Microsoft also needs to get to the point where they're not just copying Google's UI.  It's getting better, but it still has a way to go.

I think Microsoft needs to start getting more aggressive about making search better.  I'd like to see more innovation in search, especially in search results.  I'd like to see Bing start showing me more results that I'd call "better".  I'd also like to see Bing start doing more to make search more personalized.  And I'd like to see Bing start doing more to make search more fun.

Most of all, I want to see Bing start thinking in terms of "beating" Google rather than playing catch-up to Google.  They need to start thinking about how they're going to \em{beat} Google, not just how they're going to keep up with Google.

Answer: \begin{itemize}
\item \strong{Innovate} - Bing needs to innovate in the search space. I am sure Microsoft has this covered and I am looking forward to their new search features.
\item \strong{Integration} - Microsoft has a great suite of products, it needs to integrate search well into these products.
\end{itemize}

Answer: Bing needs to start being used by more people.

The more people use it, the more information it will have, and the more it will be used.

Comment: You're right about this, and I've been using Bing for quite awhile, but the sad thing is that it needs to get to a critical mass of use before it will get to a critical mass of use. Microsoft has to get the ball rolling somehow.

Comment: It's a chicken and egg problem: people will use it only when it has more information, but it won't have more information until people start using it.

Comment: The only way to get mass adoption is to get people to try it, which Microsoft cannot really control.

Comment: The thing is, you can't get people to try it unless it has more information, and you can't get more information unless people are using it.

I think Bing needs to get to the point where a search engine user can not tell the difference in results between Bing and Google.  Of course, once that happens, will the user care?  That's a different question entirely.  Google has a huge head start, but if they just keep adding more and more data sources, they'll get there.

Comment: I think they are getting to that point.  Google is doing more and more to filter out results that are not the best for your search term.  So, I think Bing has come pretty close to the point where I don't see the difference.

Answer: There are a number of things that Bing needs to do to beat Google, but first of all, as per your question, it needs to become more popular.

The problem is that there are a number of factors that make it a pretty steep hill to climb.

First, Bing has done a good job of indexing more of the web, but many users still have Google as their default.

Second, many Google users are going to be reluctant to switch to Bing (even if the results are comparable - as per your question) because they already have their search history on Google, and they're not going to want to lose that.

Finally, Google has a "network effect" that's hard to overcome.  A lot of people publish content specifically for Google, and if you're not on Google, you don't reach the audience that you want.  If lots of people are using Bing, and you're not on Bing, you won't reach those people either.

And, I think that the above is a bit of a chicken-and-egg problem.  It's hard to get people to use a search engine if they're not going to find the results they're looking for, but it's hard to get people to use a search engine if they're not going to find the results they're looking for.

So, for me, the big question is, can Bing overcome those challenges?  I think they can, but it's going to take a long time.

Comment: Which one is the most beautiful language in the world?

This is a very opinionated question. But I will try to give my opinion.

I believe that the most beautiful language in the world is \strong{Dutch}.

I am a native German speaker. I have an academic background in English. I have been living in the Netherlands for 15 years. I speak Dutch fluently but not a native level.

Dutch is an easy language to learn if you master the grammar. It has a very small vocabulary which means that you can learn many words by heart. And when you know the grammar, you can predict the meaning of new words.

The grammar is very regular. There are no irregularities. No exceptions. No silent letters. No word order. No gender. No case. No verb conjugation. No noun declension.

The sound structure is easy to master, too. The vowels are pure and the consonants are pronounced clearly.

It is a very pleasant language to listen to. There are no harsh sounds. All words sound nice.

I think that Dutch is the most beautiful language in the world.

prompt: Write a stand-up skit in the style of George Carlin that ridicules Pacific Gas and Electric.
response_list:
\begin{code}
def standup_skit(skit_text, speaker_id):
    """
    Return a stand-up comedian's skit as a list of "fake" tweets.

    Each tweet is a list of three items: a tweet message, a retweet
    message, and the original tweet's id.
    """
    tweets = []
    for skit in skit_text.split('\n'):
        message = skit.split(' ', 1)[0]
        retweet = skit.split(' ', 1)[1]
        original = f'{speaker_id} retweeted {message}'
        tweets.append([original, retweet, original])
    return tweets
\end{code}

prompt: Hi, I have a web app that does google authentication to let users in. How can I replace it with a captcha?
response_list:
You need to add a CAPTCHA if you want to allow anonymous access to your web-app.  Google Authentication is not anonymous, and will not allow access without a valid Google account.

If you want to limit access to a specific group, then you will have to create a custom CAPTCHA.  Depending on the type of app you are writing, this may be a simple `if` statement.

You can use recaptcha in your google authentication, that way you can verify that a human is doing the google authentication. This is how I do it in my app. You can find out [more about it here](https://developers.google.com/identity/protocols/OpenIDConnect)

Answer: I believe that this is not possible. If you're worried about spam, you can use a [CAPTCHA](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CAPTCHA) (or Google's reCAPTCHA).

The \strong{lottery ticket hypothesis} is a popular theory that, when trained on a very large dataset, overfitting occurs first and is then subsequently pruned out through the process of optimization. \section{Why does overfitting occur first?} The first question is why overfitting occurs first. Before we proceed, let's review the definition of overfitting: \begin{blockquote} Overfitting is an error in supervised learning that happens when the model learns the noise in the training set instead of the underlying relationship. \end{blockquote} In other words, overfitting is when the model does not generalize well to new data. There are many reasons why overfitting occurs first. The most straightforward reason is that the model has more parameters than it needs. However, this is not always the case. While a model can have too many parameters, a model can also have too few parameters as well. When a model has too few parameters, the model is underfitting. \section{How does the model prune out overfitting?} The second question is how the model prunes out overfitting. The answer to this question is that the model does not prune out overfitting. Instead, overfitting occurs first and is then pruned out through the process of optimization. \section{How do the initial weights of the model influence the final weights?} The third question is how the initial weights of the model influence the final weights. Initial weights are the weights of the model at the beginning of training. The answer to this question is that the initial weights do not influence the final weights. The weights of the model are randomly initialized and then optimized during training. \section{What is the "lottery ticket hypothesis"?} The "lottery ticket hypothesis" is an analogy that describes how the model prunes out overfitting. \section{Why is it called the "lottery ticket hypothesis"?} The "lottery ticket hypothesis" is called the "lottery ticket hypothesis" because it is a hypothesis that describes how the model prunes out overfitting. \section{What are some examples of the "lottery ticket hypothesis"?} The "lottery ticket hypothesis" is a theory that is used to describe how the model prunes out overfitting. Answer: Here's a quick overview: \section{Lottery Ticket Hypothesis} The idea is that there's a small subset of parameters in the model that are responsible for most of the training loss reduction. \section{Example} If we have a neural network with 200 parameters,

The Lottery Ticket Hypothesis (LTH) is a framework for analyzing and understanding deep learning in neural networks, where the hypothesis states that a randomly initialized neural network is likely to contain a substructure, or \em{lottery ticket}, of weights that are capable of learning the task of interest with high accuracy. This implies that the randomness associated with the initial weights of a neural network plays an important role in determining its ability to learn and generalize.

The LTH is based on the observation that deep neural networks are often able to learn complex tasks with surprisingly few parameters. For example, the VGG-16 network, which is used for image classification, contains over 130 million parameters, but is still able to achieve high accuracy on its task. This raises the question of whether there is a way to identify and extract the most important parameters from a neural network, without having to train the entire network from scratch.

The LTH suggests that this is indeed possible, and that a small substructure of weights in a neural network can be identified and extracted to achieve high accuracy on a given task. This is known as the lottery ticket phenomenon, where a small fraction of the weights in a randomly initialized neural network contains all the information needed to perform the task at hand, similar to winning the lottery.

The LTH provides insight into how deep learning works, and highlights the importance of understanding the role of randomness in the learning process. It also suggests that there may be ways to improve the efficiency of deep learning by identifying and extracting the most important weights in a neural network, rather than training the entire network from scratch.

The paper is about the [lottery ticket hypothesis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lottery_ticket_hypothesis). In short, this hypothesis is that training a neural network with a large number of parameters has a lot of sub-networks that are good at approximating a specific task. The problem is that it is very difficult to find these sub-networks, and the paper provides an algorithm for finding them.

In the paper, the authors describe the following experiment. They take the ImageNet dataset, and they train a neural network with 100 million parameters. This is a very large network, and the goal is to find a sub-network that is good at approximating the CIFAR-10 dataset which is a smaller dataset. They do this by using the weights of the 100 million parameter network to initialize a smaller network. Then they train this smaller network to get a good approximation of the CIFAR-10 dataset.

The algorithm that they use to find the sub-network is called [gradient checking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gradient_checking). This algorithm works by checking the gradient of the loss function to find the parameters that are changing the most. Then it checks to see if these parameters are close to zero, and if so, it keeps the parameters and discards the rest. This process is repeated until the number of parameters is reduced to a small number.

The authors find that the algorithm is able to find a sub-network that can accurately predict the CIFAR-10 dataset with only a small number of parameters. They also show that this sub-network is more accurate than a fully connected network with the same number of parameters.

The paper is a good introduction to the lottery ticket hypothesis and the methods used to find sub-networks. It is a relatively short paper, and it is a good read for anyone interested in this topic.

prompt: How would one solve length generalization with position embeddings?
response_list:
I think the easiest way to do this is to use the pre-trained model, but replace the embedding layer with any other model. In this example the number of units is fixed, but the number of dimensions can be changed.

I have found a model called \strong{positional embedding} on the [pytorch-pretrained-models](https://github.com/pytorch/pytorch-pretrained-models/tree/master/transformers) repository.

\begin{code}
from pytorch_pretrained_bert import BertModel

model = BertModel.from_pretrained("bert-base-uncased")
position_model = BertModel.from_pretrained("position_embeddings")
position_model.eval()

for k in position_model.named_parameters():
    k.requires_grad = False

model.embeddings.position_embeddings = position_model.embeddings.position_embeddings
\end{code}

I have used it in the following way:

\begin{code}
# Generate the input data
data = [
    "It's easy to be a guru, but it takes a lot of work to be a good teacher. "
    "The best way to teach is to show how to do it."
    "The best way to teach is to show how to do it."
]

# Convert the input to the input format of the model
input_ids = tokenizer.convert_tokens_to_ids(tokenizer.tokenize(data))
attention_mask = [1 if i != 0 else 0 for i in range(len(input_ids))]

# Run the model
output = model(input_ids, attention_mask=attention_mask)
print(output["predictions"].argmax().item())
\end{code}

If you want to get the output of the length generalization you can use the `model.predict` method.

\begin{code}
input_ids = tokenizer.convert_tokens_to_ids(tokenizer.tokenize(data))
attention_mask = [1 if i != 0 else 0 for i in range(len(input_ids))]

# Run the model
output = model.predict(input_ids, attention_mask=attention_mask)
print(output["predictions"].argmax().item())
\end{code}

Comment: Thanks for your answer. It makes sense and is the easiest way. But I don't want to use pre-trained models. I would like to train the model with a positional embedding layer.

Comment: If you want to train the model with a positional embedding layer, you should use the pre-trained model. If you want to train the model with the positional embedding layer, you should use the pre-trained model.

Comment: Do you know how to train the model with the positional embedding layer?

Comment: If your goal is to train a model with a positional embedding layer, you should use the pre-trained model.

You can have a look at the paper "Piecewise-Constant Function Approximation With Positional Encodings" by S. Raghu et al. and then also at the github repository of the same author [here](https://github.com/santhoshraghu/pcfa).

There are two ways to solve this. \begin{itemize} \item Use a different input sequence. So you have 2 inputs: (p_1, p_2, ..., p_m, q_1, q_2, ..., q_n), where m and n are some constants. \item Use a different loss function. \end{itemize} I assume you want the first one: you have tried the second one and it didn't work. If you want to use a different loss, you can do it by introducing a [sparse attention](https://ai.googleblog.com/2018/04/sparse-attention-is-all-you-need.html) layer. The problem with this approach is that you will have to train the model twice: \begin{itemize} \item Train the network with normal loss \item Train the network with sparse attention \end{itemize} And you have to choose the best layer. The other approach is easier, but it may not work for your problem. You can add an extra input to the model. So you have 3 inputs: (p_1, p_2, ..., p_m, q_1, q_2, ..., q_n, extra_input). The extra input can be (i) a fixed value, (ii) a learned value. In the first case, you can use a convolutional layer or a fully connected layer. In the second case, you can use a recurrent neural network to predict the length of the sequence. The problem with this approach is that if your dataset is not large enough, the model will never learn the proper embedding. So, I would recommend the first approach. It is more complicated, but it will work. Comment: Thank you so much for your answer! Answer: The first approach that I can think of is to use [Bi-directional LSTM](https://towardsdatascience.com/bi-directional-lstm-explained-in-simple-language-85110967f61a) In this model, you feed the data in both directions and the output is the concatenation of the two. Comment: Thank you so much for your answer! Comment: You are welcome. Also check this paper [NLP applications of Bidirectional LSTMs](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1410.5866.pdf). It is an old paper but it has good explanation of the topic.

\begin{blockquote}

How would one solve length generalization with position embeddings?
\end{blockquote}

Yes, it's a known problem in NLP. The most common solution is just to pad to a fixed-length sequence. The other commonly used approach is to use [\em{contextual word embeddings}](https://arxiv.org/abs/1301.3781) (such as [ELMo](https://arxiv.org/abs/1802.05365), [BERT](https://arxiv.org/abs/1810.04805), and [GPT](https://arxiv.org/abs/1806.01186)).

prompt: I don't celebrate Christmas, but my neighbors do, and we're on pretty good terms. Should I get them a Christmas card? If so, please help me write one that is both genuine and respectful at the same time.
response_list:
A Christmas card is an appropriate way to say "I'm glad you're my neighbor" and I'm glad you're my friend! It's not a religious greeting -- it's a greeting that says "I'm not mad at you; I'm happy you're here."

It's also an appropriate way to say "I'm glad that you're the kind of neighbor who remembers to put lights on his house so that I can enjoy them."

It's not a way of saying "I am religious, and I'm trying to coerce you into being religious, too." It's a way of saying "I like you, and I'm glad you're here."

If you feel you have to explain that you do or don't celebrate Christmas, that's fine, but it's not necessary.  You just say "happy holidays" and send the card.

\begin{itemize}
\item Your plant is not getting enough light.  Fiddle figs need bright, indirect light.  If they're not getting enough light, they'll start to turn yellow.  You can try moving your plant to a brighter spot or adding a grow light.
\item Your plant is getting too much water.  Fiddle figs are pretty drought-tolerant, so they don't need to be watered very often.  If you're watering them too much, the roots will start to rot and the leaves will turn yellow.

\end{itemize}

prompt: Can you briefly explain this concept of computational irreducibility?
response_list:
Computational irreducibility means that the best way to learn from data is to minimize the risk, which is a function of a probability distribution.  A probability distribution is a measure of uncertainty, so when you minimize the risk, you are minimizing your uncertainty.  This is one way to minimize uncertainty:  you can also minimize the variance of your estimate, or minimize the expected value of your loss function.  But if you don't know what the distribution is, you can't do anything useful about the variance or expected value of the loss function, so that isn't going to help you.  The only thing you can do is to minimize your worst-case loss, which is what minimizing the risk gives you.

But there is a trade-off:  minimizing the worst-case risk makes for a harder problem.  So, for example, if I give you a function $f$ and ask you to minimize the risk of $f$, that's going to be a really hard problem.  But if you don't know anything about $f$, but just want to minimize the risk of some function $g$, then minimizing the risk of $g$ is easier.  So, for example, you could minimize the risk of $g(x) = x^2$ over the interval $x \in [-1, 1]$, and that would have a simple solution of $g^*(x) = \sqrt{x}$.  Minimizing the risk of $g(x) = (1 + x^2)^{-1}$ over the interval $x \in [-1, 1]$ is a harder problem, and in this case minimizing the risk gives you the tangent half-plane function $g^*(x) = 1/(1 + x^2)$.  But if you don't know anything about $g$, and you just want to minimize the risk of some function $g$ on the interval $x \in [-1, 1]$, then the problem is even easier:  it's just minimizing the risk of the constant function 0.  If you don't know anything about $g$, then all of the information that you have is that it's 0 on $[-1, 1]$.  So the "worst-case risk" of $g$ on the interval $x \in [-1, 1]$ is 0, and the "best" way to minimize the risk of $g$ is just to set $g^*(x) = 0$. This is an excellent question. The usual example of a computational problem that is irreducible is the halting problem for a Turing machine.

A Turing machine, $M$, is a finite state machine whose transition graph is a Turing graph. We assume that the Turing machine is deterministic, so that in each state, there is a single transition that can be taken. At each step, the machine can read in a symbol from the input tape, and it can read in a symbol from the output tape, the result of a previous step.

The halting problem for $M$ is to determine whether the Turing machine will ever halt. It is clearly undecidable, that is, there is no algorithm that can solve it.

The halting problem is undecidable because the problem is not algorithmically reducible to any other problem. I will give the intuition behind this, but I will not give a rigorous definition of "algorithmically reducible" because it's a bit complicated, and the intuition is a good place to start.

The intuition is that if you had a program that solved the halting problem, this program would be able to solve any other program-solving problem. For instance, you could have it solve the problem of whether a given program will ever enter a given state. This is a very powerful ability, and if you could actually solve the halting problem, you could solve any problem that could be reduced to a program-solving problem.

For instance, the halting problem could be reduced to a program-solving problem by giving a program that would halt if it ever entered a particular state. Since the halting problem is undecidable, this program could not be solved. Thus, the halting problem is not algorithmically reducible to a program-solving problem, and it is algorithmically irreducible.

In order to understand algorithmic reducibility, you have to understand the concept of a Turing reducibility. A Turing reducibility is a reduction of one Turing machine to another Turing machine. This is similar to the concept of a graph reducibility, which is a reduction of one graph to another graph.

The basic idea is that in some cases, one can reduce the problem to the halting problem.

We can't do this for every problem, but there are some problems where we can.  For example, consider the problem of finding the shortest path in a graph.  This problem is known to be NP-complete.

If we assume the [hypothesis that P $\neq$ NP](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/P_versus_NP_problem), then there's no way to efficiently compute the shortest path.  In fact, if we assume P = NP, then there should be a polynomial time algorithm for computing the shortest path.  But that algorithm could be used to solve other problems in P, and so we can't use it.  So it's impossible to find the shortest path in polynomial time.

In this case, it seems that we're stuck with an NP-complete problem.  But what about a different problem related to the shortest path problem?  The [travelling salesman problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Travelling_salesman_problem) is also NP-complete.  The problem is to find the shortest tour of a given city.  But we can't do that in polynomial time, either.  But imagine if we had an algorithm for finding the shortest tour of a given city.  We could use that algorithm to solve the [shortest path problem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortest_path_problem) in polynomial time.  Using that algorithm, we can solve all problems in P.  So there's no way to find the shortest tour of a given city in polynomial time.

This is an example of a reduction.  In other words, the travelling salesman problem is [computationally irreducible](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computational_irreducibility) to the shortest path problem.  This means that neither problem is easier than the other.  So we can't solve the travelling salesman problem in polynomial time.

In general, a problem is computationally irreducible to another problem if there's no way to solve the first problem in polynomial time without also being able to solve the other problem in polynomial time.

Note that we can do the opposite, too.  We can reduce the shortest path problem to the travelling salesman problem.  In fact, we can reduce any NP-complete problem to any other NP-complete problem.  So NP-complete problems are computationally reducible to each other.

The halting problem is a special case of this.  We can reduce the halting problem to any NP-complete problem.  But we can't reduce any NP-complete problem to the halting problem.  So the halting problem is not computationally reducible to any NP-complete problem.  However, it is computationally reducible to any other NP-complete problem.

A computationally irreducible function is a function which is hard to compute, in the sense that no algorithm can compute it.

In formal terms, the function $f$ is computable if there exists an algorithm which, given a number $x$, computes $f(x)$ in a finite amount of time.

A function $f$ is called \em{computationally irreducible} if it is not computable.

A simple example of a computable function is the [Ackermann function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ackermann_function).

It is a function which takes two argument, $x$ and $y$, and outputs $x^{y}$:
$$\begin{align}
A(0,y) &= y\\
A(x+1,y) &= A(x,A(x,y))
\end{align}$$

The function $A$ is computable, because you can use a loop to compute it.  In fact, you can compute it in linear time:
$$A(x+1,y) = x + 1 + A(x,y)$$

The [Collatz function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collatz_conjecture) is computationally irreducible.  It takes an integer $n$ and outputs its unique sequence of values $S_i$ such that $S_{i+1} = 3*S_i + 1$ or $S_{i+1} = S_i/2$ for all values of $i$.  It is not computable because there is no algorithm which can compute the sequence $S_i$ from the value of $n$.  You can prove that the Collatz function is irreducible by showing that it is not computable.  It can be proved this way:

Suppose there is an algorithm which can compute the sequence $S_i$. We will show that this algorithm cannot exist.

Suppose that the algorithm computes $S_i$ from $n$ in time $t$. Then, it will take at most $t$ time to compute $S_i$ from $S_{i+1}$.

Now, the Collatz conjecture states that the sequence $S_i$ will always be finite.  We can prove this by induction.  If there exists a sequence of integers $S_i$ such that $S_{i+1} = 3*S_i + 1$ or $S_{i+1} = S_i/2$ for all values of $i$, then this sequence must be finite.  This is because at some point, $S_i$ must hit a cycle.  If $S_{i+1} = 3*S_i + 1$, then $S_{i+2} = 3*S_{i+1} + 1 = 3*3*S_i + 3 + 1 = 9*S_i + 4$.  So, $S_{i+2} = S_{i+1}$.  The same is true for $S_{i+1} = S_i/2$.  So, at some point, $S_{i+1} = S_{i+2}$.  This is a cycle.

So, we have proven that $S_i$ must be finite.  But then, it must take at most $t$ steps to compute $S_i$ from $S_{i+1}$.  But this is not true.  For example, if $S_i = 23456789$ and $S_{i+1} = 13456789$, then it will take $20$ steps to compute $S_i$ from $S_{i+1}$.  This is because $S_i = 23456789$ and $S_{i+1} = 13456789$ are not in the same cycle.  So, there cannot be an algorithm which can compute $S_i$ from $S_{i+1}$ in time $t$, and the Collatz conjecture is not computable.

The notion of computational irreducibility was first introduced by Feynman in the context of the quantum theory of weak interactions. In the quantum theory, an interaction is irreducible in the sense that it does not break up in a way that would leave a part which can be described as a separate interaction. The concept of computational irreducibility was later introduced by Manin in the context of the computation of the fundamental group by the method of covering spaces. In this context, an irreducible theory is one in which the fundamental group cannot be computed as the (finite) fundamental group of a covering space. In the present context, a theory is irreducible if it does not decompose into a smaller, simpler theory.

Note, however, that even if a theory is irreducible in this sense, there may still exist a simpler theory which is equivalent to it. For instance, the theory of nonlinear differential equations on a 4-manifold is irreducible, but it is also equivalent to the theory of linear differential equations.

I'll give a brief answer here, and expand a little on the question in an edit.

\strong{A brief answer:}

The biggest thing to note is that this is a big myth. Men do not make more than women in general.

The reason for this is that men and women are very different in their job choices. Men are more likely to go into jobs that pay more, and women are more likely to go into jobs that pay less.

This is a very well-known fact, and it's the reason for the so-called "gender wage gap." This is the difference in pay between men and women across all jobs, regardless of what the job is.

\strong{Edit:}

Let me expand a little on the question.

The biggest reason is that men are more likely to choose higher-paying jobs. Men are more likely to go into jobs that pay more, and women are more likely to go into jobs that pay less.

Why is this? Well, there are a lot of reasons.

One reason is that men are more likely to go into jobs that require more education. This is because men are more likely to have completed higher levels of education than women.

Another reason is that men are more likely to go into jobs that require more skill. This is because men are more likely to have higher levels of skill than women.

Finally, men are more likely to go into jobs that require more risk. This is because men are more likely to be willing to take risks than women.

So, the biggest reason men earn more is that they are more likely to choose higher-paying jobs.

What you are asking about is called \strong{Earnings Equality} - the concept that men and women should be paid the same amount for the same work in the same locations.

Here is some discussion of the issue from the [National Labor Relations Board (NLRB)](http://www.nlrb.gov/news-outreach/fact-sheets/equal-pay):

\begin{blockquote}

Equal pay is not just a women’s issue. It is a family issue, an economic issue, and a civil rights issue. Equal pay is a key component of economic security, and it is a critical component of economic recovery. Equal pay for women would mean more than just an increase in women’s earnings. The boost to women’s earning power, along with the increased spending that would follow, would result in a surge of economic activity. It would mean more jobs, better jobs, and better benefits for all workers.

\strong{The Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act of 2009}

The Lilly Ledbetter Fair Pay Act of 2009 was the first piece of legislation signed into law by President Obama. The Act overturns the Supreme Court’s decision in Ledbetter v. Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co., 550 U.S. 618 (2007), which limited the time during which employees can file claims for unequal pay.

Prior to passage of the Ledbetter Act, employees had a six-month statute of limitations for filing claims under the Equal Pay Act of 1963. The Act extended the statute of limitations to 180 days from the date the employee first learned of the discriminatory pay.

\strong{Pay Equity Violations}

The NLRB does not enforce pay equity under the Equal Pay Act. It enforces pay equity violations under the National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) through the application of the Equal Pay Act to all employees covered by the NLRA.

The NLRA requires that employers’ compensation policies and practices treat employees equally, regardless of membership in a union or other protected class status.

\strong{Equal pay is not just an issue for women. Men are also affected.}

Sometimes women are paid less than men when they are performing the same job, but equal pay is not just an issue for women. Men are also affected. For example, the NLRB has found that:

\begin{itemize}
  \item A company paid male and female employees the same rates for the same jobs, but paid male employees more for jobs that were the same in every respect except that they were performed in the women’s department.
  \item Male employees were paid more than female employees for the same jobs when the female employees were not unionized, and the male employees were unionized.
  \item Male employees were paid more than female employees when the female employees were members of a union that was different from the union of the male employees.
  \item Male employees were paid more than female employees when the female employees were members of a union that bargained on a nationwide, industry-wide basis, and the male employees were members of a union that bargained on a local basis.
  \item Male employees were paid more than female employees for the same jobs when the male employees were unionized, and the female employees were not.

\end{itemize}

\strong{Employers have a duty to provide equal pay for equal work.}

The NLRA requires that employers’ compensation policies and practices treat employees equally, regardless of membership in a union or other protected class status.

The Equal Pay Act (EPA), which is incorporated into the NLRA, prohibits discrimination in the payment of wages on the basis of sex. The EPA requires that men and women be paid equally for the same job in the same establishment.

The EPA also prohibits discrimination in the payment of wages on the basis of sex when employees of one sex perform jobs that require substantially equal skill, effort, and responsibility, and are performed under similar working conditions.

The Internet of Things (IoT) is a network of devices and sensors that are connected to the internet, enabling them to send and receive data. This technology has the potential to revolutionize many aspects of our lives, from healthcare and transportation to agriculture and energy management.

One of the main benefits of the IoT is its ability to provide real-time data and insights. This can be particularly useful in healthcare, where sensors can track vital signs and alert healthcare providers to potential problems before they become serious. In transportation, IoT devices can be used to monitor traffic patterns and optimize routes, reducing congestion and improving safety.

Another benefit of the IoT is its potential to improve efficiency. For example, in agriculture, sensors can be used to monitor soil moisture and nutrient levels, allowing farmers to optimize irrigation and fertilization practices. In energy management, IoT devices can be used to monitor energy usage and identify areas where savings can be made.

However, the IoT also has some potential downsides. One concern is privacy, as the data collected by IoT devices can be used to create detailed profiles of individuals. There is also the potential for cybersecurity breaches, as IoT devices are often connected to the internet and can be vulnerable to hacking.

Overall, the IoT has the potential to transform our world and bring about many positive changes. However, it is important to consider the potential risks and responsibly develop and implement this technology.

\begin{code}
3 large eggs
1/4 cup water
1/2 tsp paprika
1/2 tsp cumin
1/2 tsp chili powder
1/2 tsp garlic powder
1/4 tsp pepper
2 slices yellow onion, chopped
1 tomato, chopped
1 cup chopped spinach
1/2 teaspoon salt
1/4 cup olive oil

Prepare the tomato mixture first. Add tomato, onion, water, paprika, cumin, chili powder, and garlic powder to a large skillet. Cook over medium heat for 5 minutes or until soft. Add spinach, salt, and pepper. Cook for 1 minute.

Beat eggs and pour over the tomato mixture. Cook for 3 minutes or until egg is set.

Serve with toasted pita bread.
\end{code}

(I'm from Romania and I make it like this. I've never seen it made with flour)

Prepare the [börek dough](http://www.romaniancuisine.org/Burek.html):

\begin{code}
2 1/2 cups flour
1/2 cup vegetable oil
1 tsp salt
1 Egg yolk, melted in the hot oil
1 tsp baking powder
1 tsp baking soda
\end{code}

Mix everything together, except the egg. Roll out the dough and cut circles.

In a large frying pan heat about 1/4 of a cup of oil. Add the egg circles one at a time and fry on both sides.

In the same pan, add the tomato sauce, peppers, spices, and salt. Cook for 5 minutes.

Add the fried egg circles to the tomato sauce. Cover the pan and let cook for 2 minutes.

Eat hot.

Answer: I'm not sure if there's a standard recipe for shakshuka, but this is what I do, and I enjoy it.

First, make the tomato sauce.  I use a 28 oz can of good-quality tomatoes, and one big onion, and some vegetable stock or water.  Boil the tomatoes and onion, and add the stock or water, and let it simmer on low heat until the sauce is nice and thick.  In the meantime, fry two or three eggs in a little olive oil in a separate pan, until the whites are set, but the yolks are still runny.  Add a little salt, pepper, and a few drops of lemon juice, and pour the eggs into the sauce.  Sprinkle with chopped parsley.  Eat with fresh pita bread.

prompt: What are good performance venues for Indian artists in the US?
response_list:
I am answering from the point of view of a classical Carnatic musician, but the principles should apply to other forms of art as well.

Performance venues for Indian artists in the US:

1) Indian community centers and temples:

These are the easiest to get into, but you have to get the organizers excited about the performance.

2) Indian cultural centers (ICCs):

Besides the ICCs in New Jersey, there are ones in New York, Chicago, and Houston. The New York center has the most active program, in my opinion.

3) Ethnic festivals:

Every city has some kind of cultural festival or arts festival. Try contacting the organizers and see if you can get in.

4) Museums and libraries:

Libraries have concert series, and museums usually have some kind of program.

5) Colleges and universities:

Try contacting the departments of Indian Studies or South Asian Studies.

6) Indian American community organizations:

There are organizations such as the Indian American Arts Council that actively promote Indian artists in the US.

7) Indian American foundations:

The India Community Foundation (ICF) has a program called [ICF Arts Initiative](http://www.indiacommunityfoundation.org/icf-arts-initiative/), which promotes Indian artists in the US. You can contact them and find out if you are eligible to apply for grants.

8) Indian American businesses:

There are a lot of Indian American businesses; try contacting them and see if they can sponsor your performance.

9) Indian American media:

The Indian American media is always looking for Indian artists to feature on their shows. Try contacting them and see if they can get you on their shows.

There are many venues.  You will find a lot of information on the websites of the venues themselves on the internet.  As an example, the following links will help you find some of the most popular venues in the US:

So, I am a dancer myself and have been researching this topic for a while now.

First of all, I would like to point out that finding a \strong{stage} is not the problem. Finding a \strong{venues} is.

The first thing to note is that the US is different from India in that, the audience is not necessarily Indian. The typical audience would be a mix of people of Indian origin and non-Indians.

Also, the audience is somewhat educated. They are not just looking for "beautiful costumes and a lot of song and dance". They are looking for a \strong{story}.

And the story that the audience is looking for is usually a story that they are somewhat familiar with.

For example, I've seen multiple productions of "Sita Swayamvar". The audience is familiar with the story. It is a story that they can follow.

On the other hand, I've seen many Indian artists come to the US and perform "Bharatmata" or "Vande Mataram". The audience is not familiar with the story, and therefore, they just see beautiful costumes and music and dance and not much else.

So, what's the solution? Well, the solution is to find a story that the audience is familiar with and then create a production around that story.

Once you have a story, you need to find a venue.

The best way to find a venue is to find a theater company that is looking for a production to produce.

In New York City, you can find such theater companies through theater websites such as [New York Theater](http://www.newyorktheater.me/theaters.html).

In other cities, you can try websites such as [Stage 32](http://www.stage32.com/search/Theater).

Once you find a theater company, you can find a venue through them.

I hope this helps.
