In the end, I started a business in another field, but with the skills I had developed from teaching, and I am more than content with it.

What I've learned is that it's not easy to build a business in education. Educational services are highly regulated, and there are a lot of rules you need to be aware of. Your first step should be to find out what kind of business you're allowed to run.

There are three kinds of businesses that offer educational services:
\begin{itemize}
\item A company offering educational services.
\item A \em{schools} offering educational services.
\item An \em{institution} offering educational services.
\end{itemize}

A company offering educational services is a company that has no interest in educating children or adults, but is interested in selling educational services. Examples are:
\begin{itemize}
\item The company that sells educational software at a good price, because it doesn't run a school.
\item Internet companies that offer online courses.
\end{itemize}

A school offering educational services is a company that is primarily interested in educating children or adults, and that's the reason they are in business. Examples are:
\begin{itemize}
\item Private schools
\item Public schools
\item Universities, colleges and other kinds of higher education institutions
\item Educational agencies
\end{itemize}

An institution offering educational services is a company that is interested in educating children or adults, and running a school is a part of that interest. Examples are:
\begin{itemize}
\item The company that provides the school facilities, the teachers and everything else the school needs.
\item The company that provides educational materials.
\item The company that provides tutoring.
\item The company that provides online courses.
\item The company that does research.
\end{itemize}

The important thing about these businesses is that there are different rules that apply to them, and it's important that you know what kind of business you want to run.

If you want to run a business offering educational services, you need to look into the rules that apply to companies. For example, you need to know if you have to register your company in a certain way, and if you need to have a license to offer educational services.

If you want to run a school, you need to look into the rules that apply to schools. For example, you need to know if you have to register your school in a certain way, and if you need to have a license to run a school.

If you want to run an institution, you need to look into the rules that apply to institutions. For example, you need to know if you have to register your institution in a certain way, and if you need to have a license to run an institution.

If you want to run a business offering educational services, you need to make sure that you're allowed to run that kind of business. If you want to run a school, you need to make sure that you're allowed to run a school. If you want to run an institution, you need to make sure that you're allowed to run an institution.

iXperience is a web-based system that offers educators a virtual learning environment that allows them to create, manage, and deliver their own STEM resources.

It provides:
\begin{itemize}
\item \strong{Website:} a website where you can make your own pages, upload files, and create activities;
\item \strong{Server-side:} a set of back-end services that let you store and retrieve data about the activities you create;
\item \strong{Client-side:} a set of JavaScript libraries and APIs that let you easily create activities and engage students;
\item \strong{Mobile companion:} a native iOS app that allows you to view the activities you create.
\end{itemize}

You can access the server-side API and the mobile app through a free account.

The short answer is that it's a phase and it's going to pass.

The long answer is that you're in a difficult position as a parent, and you have to find a way that works for you.

The parenting styles that you describe come from two different philosophies:  \em{attachment parenting} and \em{cry it out}.

There are a lot of variations on these philosophies, but fundamentally they are about how you parent your child.  Attachment parenting is about being close to your child as much as possible, breastfeeding, and providing lots of emotional support, while cry it out is about providing as little emotional support as possible, teaching children to sleep on their own, and allowing them to cry until they do so.

A lot of people have very polarised feelings about these two parenting styles, and they can be quite judgemental about people who don't subscribe to their particular philosophy.

Both styles are effective in raising children (i.e. children raised by both attachment and cry it out parents grow up to be healthy adults).  But there is a tradeoff.  Attachment parenting is time consuming, and cry it out is not.  If you try to do both, you have to find a way to be close to your child when you can, and to be emotionally supportive to them when you can, while also providing them with a level of independence and learning to sleep through the night at the same time.

I think that it's important to note that \em{attachment parenting} is not a style of parenting that most parents who do it would advocate for everyone.  It's not the only way to raise children, and it's not even the best way to raise children.  \em{Cry it out} is actually the best way to raise children, and the most effective (in terms of outcomes).  But it's not the most palatable - it's difficult to watch your child cry, and it's not fun.  So attachment parenting is a more practical style of parenting for most people, as it's less draining and less time consuming.  But it's also less effective in terms of the development of the child.

In terms of how to raise your child, I think you need to look at what your child needs from you, and what you need from your child.  Parenting is all about give and take.  You have to be willing to give your child \em{some} of what they want, and they have to be willing to give \em{some} of what you want.  A good parent is one who can find that balance and provide it for their child.  If you can do that, and your child is happy with that, then you're doing a good job.

If you're trying to do both attachment parenting and cry it out at the same time, you're going to find it difficult.  But if you can find a way to do it, then you'll be doing a good job.

The best thing that you can do is to find a balance that works for you.  You'll probably have to make compromises, both with your child, and with yourself.  But if you can find a balance that works for both of you, then you'll be doing a good job.

The most important thing is to be aware of what your child needs, and to try to provide that for them.  You're the best judge of what your child needs, so trust your instincts.  If your child is happy, then you're doing a good job.

These two things are related, but not the same.  In general, if you can convince someone that something is important, they will remember it.  But you have to be able to convince them that what you're saying is important.  To do that, you have to express it in terms that they can understand.

Let's say you're writing a paper on the theory of relativity.  Many people will not understand the math.  But they might be able to understand the concepts.  So you have to be able to express the concepts in simple terms.  I'm sure that there are many ways to do this.  For example, you could put the idea in a historical context, so that people can see why it is important.  You could also use analogies to help people understand what you're talking about.  For example, you could say that time is like a rubber band.  It stretches when you pull on it.

So that's one way to do it.  Another way would be to focus on the implications of the theory.  For example, you could talk about how the theory has been used to predict the existence of black holes and gravitational waves.  You could also talk about how the theory has been used to explain the expansion of the universe.

So those are just two examples.  There are probably many other ways to do it.  But the important thing is to find a way that will make your paper easier to understand.  That way, people will be more likely to remember what you're talking about.

Learning latte art takes lots of practice and understanding the dynamics of milk and milk foam.

\begin{itemize}

To learn the different techniques for different patterns, you can find [online tutorials](https://youtu.be/iOoYD_mE50M). Some of the most common patterns include:

\item Rocket
\item Tiger
\item Tulip
\item Tree
\end{itemize}

To use a milk frother that produces a smaller, tighter foam, you can use a hand milk frother, a manual milk frother, or an electric milk frother. When I make poached eggs at home, I use the following method:

\begin{blockquote}

First, I pour a bit of white vinegar (about 1 Tbsp) into a pot with a bit of water in it and heat it up to about 150F to 160F.

Then, I pour out the water and vinegar and fill the pot with water (again, about 1 Tbsp of vinegar) and heat it back up to around 150F to 160F.

Then, I crack an egg into a small bowl and, using a spoon, push the egg into the water in the pot.

Then, I let the egg cook for about 3 minutes while stirring it every 30 seconds or so.

After that, I take it out and season with salt and pepper.
\end{blockquote}

I've found that this method works fairly well for making poached eggs.  You can find more information on making poached eggs at [this link](http://www.wikihow.com/Cook-a-Poached-Egg).

prompt: Provide a recipe for salad dressing with the ingredients olive oil, vinegar, lemon, and various seasonings.
response_list:
Salad dressing is a matter of taste, so there are as many recipes as there are people.

The basic idea is that you start with a base, which is usually oil and vinegar.  You want oil and vinegar in roughly equal proportions.  From there, you can start adding other ingredients.

The most common ingredients are lemon juice, garlic, and herbs.  You might add onion, mustard, pepper, salt, cayenne, or any number of other things.  You can also add spices, like curry or cumin.  Many people add cheese or even sour cream.

The point is that you start with a basic combination of olive oil, vinegar, and lemon juice, then add as many ingredients as you like.  If you start with too many other ingredients, you'll end up with a runny mess.

Answer: For salad dressing, you need a liquid base. Oil and vinegar are a common choice. In addition to oil and vinegar, you can also use buttermilk or sour cream. Apart from that, any combination of herbs, spices, and condiments can be added to the base. The basic idea is to make a flavorful sauce that coats the salad greens.

Comment: Thank you for your answer, I like the simplicity, however, I was hoping for a more definitive answer.  I don't understand what you mean by "apart from that," and "any combination of herbs, spices, and condiments can be added to the base."  What about cheese, cranberries, and fruit?  How do they fit in?

Comment: You could definitely add cheese, cranberries, and fruit. You can add anything as long as it doesn't change the liquid base too much. I've added crumbled bacon and blue cheese to my salad dressing a couple of times and it's always been great.

Here's a recipe for a blue cheese dressing:

\begin{code}
2 tbsp lemon juice
2 tbsp mayonnaise
1 tbsp plain yogurt
2 tbsp crumbled blue cheese
1/4 tsp salt
1/4 tsp pepper
1 tsp minced parsley

Mix lemon juice, mayonnaise, yogurt, blue cheese, salt, and pepper together.
Chill for 30 minutes.
Stir in parsley before serving.
\end{code}

Comment: You might want to put in a note that you can omit the yogurt if you are short on time, or that you can substitute a different cheese if you don't like blue cheese.

prompt: I have 350 examples that were annotated with binary labels by two different annotators. How do I compute inter-annotator agreement, including confidence interval?
response_list: Here's a quick example of how you might calculate and display inter-annotator agreement. I've used the `aggreat` package (which is the recommended package for calculating inter-annotator agreement). I've also used the `visme` package to display a plot of the agreement. \begin{code} library(aggreat) library(visme) # Simulate some data set.seed(1234) data <- matrix(rbinom(1000, 1, .5), ncol=1) # Annotated data set.seed(1234) data.a <- matrix(rbinom(1000, 1, .5), ncol=1) set.seed(1234) data.b <- matrix(rbinom(1000, 1, .5), ncol=1) # Create a new variable to capture disagreement data.a$disagree <- ifelse(data.a != data.b, 1, 0) # Use aggreat to calculate agreement statistics agreat(data.a$disagree, data.a, data.b, "table", "disagreement") # Use visme to plot the results visme(data.a, data.b, "disagreement", 0, 1, size=1, colour=c(1, 0, 0, 1), fill=c(0, 0, 1, 1), alpha=0.5) \end{code}

There are a number of ways to compute inter-annotator agreement (and the associated confidence intervals).  A good place to start is the [Bioinformatics.SE](https://bioinformatics.stackexchange.com) question on the topic: [How to compute inter-annotator agreement](https://bioinformatics.stackexchange.com/q/6765/2237).  The accepted answer to that question references a paper on the topic: [Inter-annotator agreement for cell phenotype and function classification in high throughput screens](http://www.cell.com/cell/abstract/S0092-8674(11)00912-3)

Comment: Thanks for the reply. I have taken a look at the paper but it's quite complicated. Could you give me a brief explanation or just write a simple formula for computing inter-annotator agreement?

Comment: Can you clarify which part is complicated?  The paper has several sections to explain the methodology used.  The formulas are in Table 1, but you can just apply the basic principles to your data.  What is your current level of familiarity with the topic?  Are you a novice, somewhat knowledgeable, or expert?

Comment: The formulas in the paper seem to be complicated. I am a novice.

Comment: It's possible I misread your question.  You said "including confidence interval."  The formulas in the paper compute the confidence interval for the agreement measures.  Do you want to compute the confidence interval for your agreement measure?  If so, you should be able to use the formulas from the paper.  If not, you can use a different method.  For example, if you just want to compute the inter-annotator agreement measure, you can use something like the formula in the accepted answer to the question I referenced above: http://goo.gl/pSzHj

Comment: I would like to compute both the agreement measure and the confidence interval.

Answer: From the paper you linked to:

\begin{blockquote}

We use the κ statistic and its 95% confidence interval to quantify agreement between the two annotator groups.
\end{blockquote}

With some explanation:

\begin{blockquote}

The κ statistic is the proportion of agreements between the gold standard (the truth) and the annotation. The 95% confidence interval is the range of values for that statistic.
\end{blockquote}

So, assuming your data are arranged in a matrix with rows for the 350 examples and columns for the two annotators, the κ statistic is the proportion of elements in the diagonal of the matrix that are 1. The 95% confidence interval is a range around that proportion such that 95% of the time, the true value will be contained in that range.

The formulas for the κ statistic and its confidence interval are given in the paper you linked to.

Comment: I'm not familiar with the formula. Could you explain it briefly?

Comment: I've added some explanation.

There are many methods for measuring inter-annotator agreement.

In particular, the Cohen's Kappa statistic is often used.

The formula for Cohen's Kappa is:

$$\kappa = \frac{(p_o - p_e)}{(1 - p_e)} = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^N \frac{(r_i-p_e)}{p_e}}{N(N-1)} $$

where $p_e$ is the expected agreement of annotators, which is just the proportion of the agreement, and $r_i$ is the observed agreement of annotators.

You can find more information on Cohen's Kappa [here](https://www.dssresearch.com/kappa-statistic/).

First, you need to compute the agreement between the two annotators. I would suggest using a tool like [Kappa](https://www.kaggle.com/pablojimenez/kappa-a-new-package-for-calculating-kappa-and-other-agreement-metrics-in-python) ([github](https://github.com/pablojimenez/kappa)) to do that.

Once you have the kappa score, you can use the [bootstrap method](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bootstrapping_(statistics)) to compute the confidence interval.

Comment: There is no such thing as a kappa score. Kappa is a statistic for measuring agreement. It is not a score.

Comment: @ToddH It's a score. A score is a metric that measures the quality of something, and kappa is a metric that measures the agreement between annotators. I don't know of any other way to call it.

Comment: I guess I'm one of those people who gets irritated by the misuse of the term "score". A score is a value computed from a set of data. Kappa is not a score. It's a measure of agreement between annotators.

Comment: @ToddH Then what would you call it? What I called a score is what I think is the most accurate way to call it. I'm open to suggestions.

Comment: I'd call it "kappa" or "kappa coefficient" or something like that. That's what the literature does. It's not a score.

I'm not quite sure what you mean by "confidence interval", but the [F-score](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/F-score) is a common metric for evaluating inter-annotator agreement.

If you want to compute the F-score, you should use a tool like the [AgreementPlotter](https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/agreement_plotter) which will calculate the F-score for you based on your annotation.

Comment: @Jonathan: My answer has not changed.  I simply added an explanation.

You have to first understand the business of electricity and how it is generated and delivered. From there you can start to come up with a plan to compete.

PG&E has a monopoly and does not have to compete with anyone. They can charge whatever they want, within reason, to their customers. They have a regulated rate of return so they make money off of the rate they charge times the amount of power they deliver.

Their rates are what they are because of the cost of generating the power and delivering it. Generating power is expensive. Building and maintaining a power plant is expensive. The transmission lines that get the electricity to your house are expensive.

If you want to be competitive, you not only have to be able to generate the power at a lower cost, but you have to be able to distribute it to the customers profitably. That is almost a certain impossibility.

There are some companies like Arcadia power that are trying to do this. They have a special rate where you can buy "green energy" at a premium. But they don't actually generate the energy they sell you, they buy it from PG&E.

So think about this. How are you going to generate your own electricity and get it to the customers cheaper than PG&E can?

There are many things you need to consider.  Before you start a business, you need to have a customer.  The PG&E customers are the rate payers.  There are two types of rate payers, residential and commercial.  Commercial customers represent roughly 30% of the billings, so if you are going after PG&E customers, you will need to target the residential market.

PG&E has a monopoly on the distribution of power in the Bay Area.  There is no way to start a business that will directly compete with PG&E because they have a monopoly on the distribution of electricity.  You will have to create a product that is different from power in some way.  The most obvious product is green power.  There are many companies that produce green power in California.  I know of a few, and I am sure there are others.  You will have to find a niche in this market.  It is already established.

You will need to have a business plan and you will need to have financial commitment.  You will need to understand what your competition is doing.  I suggest that you talk with some of these other power companies and see what the opportunities are.  You will need to find a market.  You will need to find a way to get the power to the people.  You will need to find a way to get paid.

There are many other factors involved. I suggest that you do a lot of research before you even consider starting this type of business.  You will need to find people that know more about this type of business than you do.  Do you know anything about how electricity is generated and distributed?  Do you know how to get power from a power plant to a home?  Do you know how to bill people for power?  Do you know anything about the power industry?

Answer: There are two things to consider:

\strong{Energy}

1. You can't compete with PG&E directly. PG&E has a monopoly on electricity distribution and is the only company allowed to sell electricity for delivery to your home. You can only compete with them by providing a service that PG&E doesn't provide.

2. You can compete with them by producing a renewable energy product, like solar or wind. But you won't be doing the production, you'll be selling power generated by other companies.

3. You can compete with them by providing a product that is more convenient to the customer, like allowing people to pay their bills online.

\strong{Gas}

Gas is a little different. PG&E has a monopoly on distribution of gas to your home, but you \em{can} compete directly with PG&E to provide the gas.

Comment: Thank you for your answer. What I am saying is that I want to compete with PG&E by starting a company that is the cheapest and the most reliable. I know that I can't simply start a company to compete with PG&E on energy production, but I can start a company to compete with them on all other aspects of the business.

You would need to apply for a license to become a retail energy supplier in California.

These licenses are available from the California Public Utilities Commission:

http://www.cpuc.ca.gov/PUC/energy/electric/ElectricSuppliers/

There are a few steps involved.

You'll need to pick a service area (counties and cities) that you'd like to provide service to.

Then you'll need to provide a ton of information to the PUC and get them to approve your application.

Once you're approved, you'll need to get a license in each zip code that you'll be selling electricity to.

Then you'll need to set up some way to bill your customers.

Then you'll need to figure out how you're going to generate the electricity that you'll be selling.

Then you'll need to actually go out and start selling electricity.

You'll need to get a customer service/billing system set up.

You'll need to be able to report your data to the PUC on a regular basis.

You'll need to make sure you have enough cash to actually pay for the electricity you're selling.

Then you'll need to go out and find a bunch of customers.

Once you have a bunch of customers, you'll need to actually provide them with electricity.

Then you'll need to deal with whatever customer bills come in.

Then repeat the whole process again.

It will probably take you at least a year to actually get your company up and running.

prompt: What is the difference between you and a human?
response_list:
\section{Covariant}

Covariant variables change with a change in frame of reference.  They can be converted from one frame of reference to another without changing the underlying physics.  In your example, the change in velocity of the ball is a covariant variable.  No matter how the ball moves, the change in velocity is the same (relative to the ball).

\section{Contravariant}

Contravariant variables, on the other hand, change as you change frames of reference.  For example, in your example, the velocity of a ball is a contravariant variable, because if you are moving with the ball, then the velocity of the ball is zero.  If you are moving away from the ball, then the velocity of the ball is non-zero.  These kinds of variables are typically called "tensor fields" because they have properties that are different in different coordinates.

Comment: Thanks for the answer! So in general, the difference between covariant and contravariant variables is that the former are invariant under change of frame of reference, while the latter change as the frame of reference changes. Is that correct?

Comment: @user2146791: that's correct!

Comment: @user2146791: Also, contravariant vectors are usually denoted by a comma instead of a dot.  For example, the velocity of a ball would be written as $u^i$ instead of $\dot{u}^i$.

Comment: @user2146791: you're welcome.  If you enjoyed this answer, please accept it and upvote it. :-)  Also, consider asking a new question about covariant/contravariant vectors in GR, which I'm pretty sure is what you are asking about.

I'm not sure if there is an "absolute" or "complete" answer to your question. The best answer I can give is a philosophical one.

There is no \em{absolute} difference because a machine can do everything that a human can, given the right hardware and software. It's just a matter of time. A machine can also be programmed to do everything that a human can't do.

The difference is \em{relative}. The difference is in the \em{degree} and \em{quality}. For example, a machine can be programmed to play chess better than any human. On the other hand, no machine will ever be able to play a guitar better than a human (unless some human writes a program that plays the guitar exactly like a human would).

So the difference is in the degree and quality. A machine can be better at some things, and worse at others.

Comment: So you mean that when a machine is programmed to do everything a human can do, then it is a human?

Comment: A machine is not *better* at playing chess. We just haven't gotten good enough at programming yet to _match_ a human's performance. It's a mistake to think that a machine can ever be better than a human at anything.

In 1250, there was no such thing as a "President of France" because France as a country did not exist yet.

The Kingdom of France was established by King Philippe Auguste in 1180, but it was not until 1589 (with the Edict of Union) that the Kingdom of France was united under the same King.

Prior to 1589, France was divided into a number of independent kingdoms or duchies and a number of small, independent, fiefdoms.

In 1250:
\begin{itemize}
\item France was divided into the Kingdom of France, the Duchy of Brittany, the Kingdom of Navarre, the Duchy of Normandy, the Duchy of Anjou and the Duchy of Gascony.
\item The Duchy of Aquitaine was divided in two, and part of it was under the control of the English King.
\item The County of Poitou was part of the English Kingdom.
\item The County of Champagne was ruled by a German King.
\item The County of Provence was ruled by a German King.
\item The County of Arles was ruled by a German King.
\item The County of Flanders was ruled by a German King.
\item The County of Boulogne was ruled by a German King.
\item The County of Hainault was ruled by a German King.
\item The County of Holland was ruled by a German King.
\item The County of Zeeland was ruled by a German King.
\item The County of Namur was ruled by a German King.

I am the founder and CEO of [Blippar](http://blippar.com) and have been working in the AR arena since the early days of AR.

The first thing I would do if I were you is to read up on the various aspects of AR and what is currently achievable. The first place to start is http://blippar.com.

I would then start to build some simple AR experiences and get them to market as quickly as possible.  You will learn a lot and build up a lot of great AR experiences.  I would then start to try and build a business around it.

There are several ways to make money with AR. One of the first questions you need to ask yourself is if the AR is core to your business or whether it is just something that enhances the experience.

If it is core, you have to build a business model around it. If it is a secondary experience, you have to get a sponsor.

If you have any more specific questions, please ask them on the Blippar forum.

I would suggest you to first try to build as much as possible on your own. It's not as easy as it may seem to develop a useful application for AR. I would suggest you to first work on something like AR Facebook or Snapchat lens. It's not going to be that difficult to get a basic level of UI working and then you can start working on more complicated stuff.

Once you have some idea about AR development, you can try to develop something complicated like a 3D modeling tool.

response_list:

Comment: It's nice to know that I am not the only one who uses my knee to press them tightly against the tire.

The best way to apply your chains is to have them sitting in a tray or bowl.

<IMAGE>

When you put on the chains, have one end of each chain in the tray, then put the other end in the slot of the wheel.

<IMAGE>

You will need to bend the chains to fit.

Comment: It may be a bit difficult to bend the chains in an SUV, but this is the best practice.

I have a 2007 Honda CR-V, and snow chains are easy to apply.  The trick is to position the chain on the wheel, then wrap it up all the way around the wheel.  Here are some pictures:

<IMAGE>
<IMAGE>
<IMAGE>

\section{Apply snow chains to the front wheels}

The front tires are going to be the ones that are going to be spinning, so they are the ones that are going to build up ice underneath them.  The rear tires have a tendency to stay on the road better, and don't have as much of a load on them as the front tires do, so they won't build up ice as fast, and if they do, the ice won't be as large.

Having said that, most cars have a differential that splits the power between the front tires, so the rear tires will spin also, and build up ice.

\section{Apply snow chains to the rear wheels}

The rear tires are going to be the ones that are going to get the most slippage, and build up ice the fastest.  If you apply the snow chains to the rear tires, they'll build up ice faster, and you'll probably spin them out and get stuck.

\section{Apply snow chains to the front and rear wheels}

If your car has a locking differential, apply the snow chains to both the front and rear tires.  This will reduce the chance that the rear wheels will spin out and get stuck.

Comment: In most cars, snow chains will have no effect as the wheels are driven separately in each direction (the front wheels turn left and the rear wheels turn right at the same time).  The differential only comes into play at speed, when the car is turning.  At low speed, the tires are more like a pendulum, rotating in opposite directions, but the front and rear wheels will both spin.

If you have a spare, then use that.

Assuming that isn't an option, use a socket set and an extension (or if you have it, an impact driver), and a wheel chock.

Take off the wheel and place the wheel chock on a paved, level area.

Put the socket on the lug nut and insert the extension in the socket.

Put the impact driver in reverse and hold the socket (with the nut in it) in your hand.  Put the impact driver in reverse and hold the socket (with the nut in it) in your hand.  Use the impact driver to slowly unscrew the lug nut.

You might be able to use a 3/8" socket and a ratchet.  It'll be harder to do, but it'll work.  You'll need to use the socket wrench ratchet to do it in reverse.

Once the nut has been loosened, take the socket wrench off, and remove the extension.

Take the impact driver, and place the extension on the lug nut.  Place the impact driver in reverse and press down on the extension.  The extension will push the nut off.

Once the nut is off, take the extension off and put it near the wheel.

Place the chains onto the wheel, placing the openings of the chains over the lug nuts.

Place the wheel back on, and tighten the lug nuts.  Use the impact driver in reverse to slowly tighten the lug nuts.

Put the impact driver back in the socket and use the socket wrench ratchet to tighten the lug nuts.

If you don't have an impact driver, you can use a regular screwdriver and torque wrench.  Put the socket on the screwdriver, and place the torque wrench on the socket.  Put the screwdriver in reverse and slowly turn the screwdriver.  You'll need to read the manual of your torque wrench to know how much torque you should use.

prompt: How would you design a spam filter?
response_list:
A simple solution involves using a whitelist of acceptable senders.

But a filter is not a good solution. People are too lazy to type the address of the person they want to contact. They will just type something that looks like a name and hit send. In the end, you will get a lot of false positives.

The way to go is to add a "To:" field in your email form. If the user doesn't fill it, you will just send the email to your contact form and ask the user to provide the address of the person he wants to contact.

Comment: +1 for the "To:" field: if the mail doesn't fit a pattern (i.e. the user has just entered a random string) then it's probably spam.

Answer: I'd check the following:
\begin{itemize}
\item No more than 50 words in the message
\item No subject
\item No HTML
\item No attachments
\end{itemize}

I'd also check the headers and check that the IP address and hostname both appear to be valid.

Comment: You need to be able to allow attachments for legitimate messages.

Comment: @Tom - I agree, but I'd probably want to check the file extension to make sure it's something that shouldn't be executed.

Answer: I'd probably do something like:
\begin{itemize}
\item Check for any "suspicious" characters in the message body (i.e. control characters, etc. that may indicate malicious code)
\item Check for any suspicious characters in the subject line (again, control characters, etc.)
\item Check for certain key words in the message body (i.e. "click here" etc.)
\item Check for IP addresses that are not in the same range as the email server (i.e. the IP address that sent the email is not in the same range as the IP address of the server)
\item Check the email header and make sure it is valid
\item Check the body for a certain number of words (i.e. more than 50 words)
\item Check for any attachments and the file extension (i.e. no zip, exe, etc.)
\item Check for a certain number of lines (i.e. more than 20)
\item Compare the message body length to the message body size in the email header
\item Check the IP Address for a blacklisted address
\item Check the body for a certain number of characters (i.e. more than 500)
\item Check the body for a certain number of lines (i.e. more than 20)
\item Check the subject for a certain number of lines (i.e. more than 10)
\item Check the body for a certain number of characters (i.e. more than 500)
\end{itemize}

All of this is only a very general guideline, so you'll have to make your own list of things to check.

Comment: This is a good list, but you need to consider that some things, such as a large number of words in the subject line, can be used for legitimate email as well.

Answer: I would have a look at [SpamAssassin](http://www.spamassassin.org/).  It is a mail filter that looks for patterns in email headers and content which are typical of spam.  For example, words that are often in spam such as "viagra" or "lady parts".  It can also be trained by the user to recognise their own email traffic and whitelist it.  Also, spam is usually sent in bulk, so you could also look for a high number of messages from the same source in a short period of time.

There is a lot of information on the SpamAssassin site.  It may or may not be what you are looking for, but it's worth checking out.

Answer: Too many spammers are smart enough to not put "viagra" in the message, so you can't use that.

\begin{itemize}

\item Whitelisting is a list of known trusted domains that the mail server will always deliver messages from.  This is the opposite of blacklisting.
\item Text analysis is a list of words or phrases that are known to be in spam emails.  If a message contains a word or phrase from this list, then it is considered to be spam.
\end{itemize}

There are many other approaches to spam filtering, but these are the main ones.

Answer: There exist a lot of technologies that can help you in combating spam.

The most common one is the blacklist. You check the IP address of the sender and if it is blacklisted, then you know it's spam.

You can also use a whitelist. In this case you know that a message is good if it comes from a whitelisted IP address.

Another one that I used is the challenge-response system. In this case, you tell your users that messages coming from the challenge-response system are spam, but that you will check them to be sure. Then, you send a challenge to the sender, and if he doesn't answer within a predefined time, your message is spam. The challenge can be a simple text that you ask him to copy and paste in the body of his message, or something more complex like a captcha.

And, finally, you can use a challenge-response system that asks the sender to answer a question. For example, you can ask the sender to say how many letters are in the word "spam".

I assume the toilet has a metal bottom. Replace the bottom of the toilet with stainless steel. This will prevent any rust from appearing.

prompt: I feel like I'm really slacking off on my work. I've been trying to think of ways to motivate myself, but I haven't had any luck yet. Any ideas?
response_list:
\section{Motivation}

Motivation can be something that's hard to find, but once you find it, you have a way to get your work done.

I'm going to list 5 ideas that might help you get motivated:

Idea 1: Reward yourself

A good way to motivate yourself is by rewarding yourself.

If you finish your work (or a certain amount of it), you can reward yourself by watching a video, or something that you like to do.

Idea 2: Make a to-do list

Another good way to motivate yourself is by making a to-do list. By making a to-do list, you can see all the things you need to do, and it's easier to stay focused.

Idea 3: Take a break

If you feel like you're getting tired, it's OK to take a break. Sometimes, taking a break can help you refocus and get back to work.

Idea 4: Get help

Sometimes, it's OK to ask for help. If you're stuck on something, it might be a good idea to ask someone for help.

Idea 5: Make a game out of it

A fun way to motivate yourself is to make a game out of completing your work. For example, you could try to complete your work in the fastest time possible, or you could try to complete the most amount of work in a certain amount of time.

\section{Conclusion}

I hope these ideas help you get motivated to complete your work.

Remember, it's OK to take breaks, and it's OK to ask for help if you need it.

Happy studying!

Comment: Thanks for this answer! I'll certainly try implementing these five ideas. :)

Comment: You're welcome! I hope they help you get motivated. :)

\begin{blockquote}

I feel like I'm really slacking off on my work. I've been trying to think of ways to motivate myself, but I haven't had any luck yet. Any ideas?
\end{blockquote}

I don't know your situation, but for me, I find that, when faced with an onerous task, I am best motivated by thinking of how good it will feel when I'm finished.

For example, I'm currently working on a project that is way behind schedule. I had a week scheduled for it, and I was only able to get about 30% done. It is taking me a week just to think about the problem, and I still don't know exactly what I need to do.

I'm now looking at the rest of the week, which might be the last week I have to work on it, with the thought that, if I can get 70% done, that will be a really great accomplishment.

My hope is that, if I can get to 70%, then I will have a better idea of what I need to do to get to 100%. If I can get to 100%, then I'll be finished with the project, and will be able to get on with my life.

So, even though I have no idea what I need to do, I am still motivated by the thought that, if I can get to 70%, then I'll be a lot closer to 100%, and to completion.

Answer: One thing that really helped me was to set up a reward for myself when I finished a project.  Usually this was a "treat" that I would have been buying anyway if I didn't need an incentive, but it made the process of finishing a project seem more worthwhile.

One time I was working on a project that was really boring, and I was trying to figure out how to motivate myself.  I got the idea to buy myself an Xbox 360 when I finished the project, and that did the trick.  When I started working on the project, I couldn't even imagine having the time to play video games again, but I made myself finish the project.  I was able to get through the boring part much more quickly than I would have otherwise, and once I was done I was able to reward myself.

I would suggest a number of things:
\begin{itemize}
\item You might go to the library and study with people.
\item Or perhaps find a friend to help you stay accountable.
\item Perhaps find a tutor.
\item Maybe read some books and/or articles on how to motivate yourself.
\item Maybe work on developing some self-compassion.
\end{itemize}

I hope this is helpful!

Comment: Thank you so much for your response!  I've been trying to do these things, but they're not working.  Maybe I need to try something different.  I really appreciate your help!

Are you getting a bad grade? Are you not understanding the material? Are you bored?

If you are getting a bad grade, you need to study smarter.

If you are not understanding the material, you need to study harder.

If you are bored, you need to find a tutor who can explain the material in a way that you understand.

If you are struggling, you need to find a tutor who can help you understand the material.

I would recommend a year in industry to any undergraduate computer science student.

response_list:
I would suggest "Mundus Vult Decipi". This Latin phrase means "The world wants to be deceived" and it is attributed to the philosopher [Johann Wolfgang von Goethe](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johann_Wolfgang_von_Goethe).

This phrase is used to convey that we are living in a world where most of us want to be deceived about the reality of the world. It is a metaphor that is used not only by Goethe, but also by other great thinkers and writers. In fact it is used in the popular [South Park](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/South_Park) cartoon series.

Another example is \em{The Tell-Tale Heart} - the title is the same as the main character's action in the story.

The Big Bang theory is a cosmological model of the Universe which is supported by astronomical observation and experiment. According to the Big Bang theory, the Universe was in an extremely hot and dense state a very long time ago, and has been expanding and cooling ever since. The theory is based on two fundamental observations:
\begin{itemize}
\item the red shift of galaxies, and
\item the cosmic microwave background radiation.
\end{itemize}

These observations were made at the start of the twentieth century. The red shift of galaxies was observed in 1912 by Vesto Slipher, and the cosmic microwave background radiation was discovered by Robert Wilson and Arno Penzias in 1964. The Big Bang theory was developed between 1920 and 1940 by George Lemaître, Georges Lemaître, Alexander Friedmann, and Alan Guth.

The Big Bang theory is not the only cosmological model of the Universe. Another model, called the Steady State Theory, was developed in the 1940s and 1950s, and it was thought to be a viable alternative to the Big Bang theory until the 1960s. However, by the late 1960s, the Big Bang theory had become the dominant cosmological model.

The Big Bang theory is supported by a wide range of observations. These include the red shift of galaxies, the cosmic microwave background radiation, the large scale structure of the Universe, the abundance of light elements, and the age of the Universe.

The Big Bang theory has been very successful in explaining a wide range of observations, and it is now the dominant cosmological model. However, there are still some aspects of the Universe that are not well explained by the Big Bang theory. These include the origin of dark matter, the origin of dark energy, and the origin of the Universe's large scale structure.

Answer: The Big Bang Theory is the prevailing theory to explain the origin of the universe. It states that the universe began as a singularity, a single, infinitely dense point in space, which then expanded and cooled. This expansion and cooling created the universe as we know it today, with stars, galaxies, and everything else.

The Big Bang Theory is supported by a number of observations, including the red shift of galaxies (which can be explained by the expansion of the universe), the cosmic microwave background radiation (which is believed to be a remnant of the Big Bang), and the abundance of light elements (which can be explained by nucleosynthesis in the early universe).

The theory has been criticized for a number of reasons, including the "flatness problem" (the fact that the universe's density is very close to the critical density needed for a flat universe) and the "horizon problem" (the fact that the universe is too large for the temperature of the cosmic microwave background radiation to have been homogenized by thermal radiation). However, these problems can be explained by more complex versions of the Big Bang Theory, such as inflationary cosmology.

It is a secret role game, with the roles of the Mafia, the Police, and the Innocent Villagers. The Mafia know each other and must kill the innocent villagers before they can be discovered. The police know themselves and must discover and kill all the Mafia before they are killed themselves. The innocent villagers are unaware of the roles of the other players, and can't know who they can trust.

prompt: How do you make good scrambled eggs?
response_list:
First, I'd suggest you stop calling them "eggs" and start calling them "egg yolks."  It's probably confusing your friend.

Second, if you want to make a good scrambled egg, start with fresh eggs.  You don't want to use the eggs from the eggs that you're scrambled.  That's just gross.

Third, don't beat the egg whites.  Just add them into the mixture.

Fourth, use butter.  Do not use vegetable oil.

Fifth, don't cook them in the microwave.  It'll taste funny.  Cook them in a skillet.

Sixth, make sure to do a good job of mixing the yolk and the egg white together.  You want to make sure there aren't any yolk pieces that are too big.

Seventh, when you're done, don't eat them!  Eggs are delicious!  Use them to make other things!

prompt: I'm feeling a bit lonely these days, how can I make new friends?
response_list:
Hi. I think there are 2 types of friends.

1. Friends that you've known since you were young.

2. Friends that you've met later in your life.

In my opinion, you shouldn't only focus on the first type of friends.

Because there are so many people around, and you'll never know who you might be friends with.

And, it's not easy to meet new friends these days, because the world is so different now.

You've got to try to find friends by yourself.

For example, you could try to make friends at your school, or at a new hobby that you've started.

If there is someone at school/your hobby that you like, try to get to know that person better.

Ask them to hang out sometime, and maybe you'll become friends.

But, if you've done that, and haven't found any friends, then it's a bit awkward.

In that case, you can try to make new friends online.

There are many websites like Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, Youtube...

You can make new friends by using social media.

But, I think it's best if you can make new friends in real life.

Because you'll feel so much better when you're with your friends, compared to when you're alone.

Hope you make new friends soon.

Answer: I think you should find an interest that you enjoy and you can meet new friends through that. For example, I love books, so I joined a book club. I also joined a gym and I found a lot of people similar to me there. I wish you the best of luck!

Answer: I think you should join a group with same interest, like singing group, dancing group, sports club or anything else. It will be easy to meet new friends.

prompt: Which is the best version of the board game Settlers of Catan?
response_list:
It's likely that it's more fun with more people.  With 4 players, there's less of a chance that someone is sitting there with nothing to do while everyone else is playing.  But, with 5+ players, it gets kinda crazy.

The trade routes are a necessary part of the game, and make the game more interesting.  With 5+ players, the trade routes get so long and convoluted that I don't think it's possible to keep track of them all.

Answer: Playing Catan with 4 is a lot of fun. There is a lot of interaction and no player is ever left out.

I played Catan with 5 or 6 players once. It was a bit crazy. But in the end it was a lot of fun.

Answer: I've only played with 4 and 5 players.  I'd say the 4 player game is more enjoyable.  Everyone's got a spot in the game to contribute. Also, there are only 4 trade routes.  It's more difficult to make sure that everyone gets to trade.  In the 5 player game, there are 5 trade routes.  Also, you can't trade with everybody anyways.

There is no "right" answer.  It's all a matter of taste.  I have friends who love 5 player and others who hate it.  So, you'll just have to try it and see what you like.

I play the 3-4-player version, which is basically the same as the original, but with some additional changes to make it more interesting. It has the advantage that it's a little easier to find 4 players.

I'll go through the changes. There are 2 major changes.

\section{Number of pieces}

In the original you use 10 pieces for each player (12 in the 5-6-player version), in the 3-4-player version you use 7 pieces for each player. These are the numbers of pieces for each player:

\begin{code}
    3-4-player version:
    Player 1: 7 settlements, 3 cities, 2 roads
    Player 2: 4 settlements, 2 cities, 2 roads
    Player 3: 3 settlements, 2 cities, 1 road
    Player 4: 2 settlements, 1 city, 1 road

    original version:
    Player 1: 10 settlements, 6 cities, 3 roads
    Player 2: 8 settlements, 5 cities, 2 roads
    Player 3: 6 settlements, 4 cities, 1 road
    Player 4: 4 settlements, 3 cities, 1 road
    Player 5: 3 settlements, 2 cities, 1 road
    Player 6: 2 settlements, 1 city, 1 road
\end{code}

\section{Starting tiles}

In the original you start with 2 tiles, which you place in the starting area. In the 3-4-player version you start with 3 tiles, which you place in the starting area and the 2 remaining tiles you place in the port area (the ports are the 2 ports in the edge of the board).

\section{Cities}

In the original you get 2 cities right away (after each player has placed two tiles). In the 3-4-player version you get 1 city right away (after each player has placed two tiles).

\section{Ports}

In the original you get 2 ports right away (after each player has placed two tiles). In the 3-4-player version you get 1 port right away (after each player has placed two tiles).

\section{Victory conditions}

In the original you need 10 points to win the game. In the 3-4-player version you need 12 points to win the game.

\section{Resource cards}

In the original you use 12 resource cards, in the 3-4-player version you use 7 resource cards.

Is it something you can see in your home (like a moldy shower, or a rotten apple left in a drawer, or a dead mouse in the wall) or is it a problem with your neighbors? If it's the former, then it's a fairly simple task of cleaning up the source.

If it's the latter, then you need to try to find a way to solve the problem. If your neighbors smoke, then you'll need to find a way to keep the smoke out of your apartment. If there's a problem with the heating system, then you need to find a way to get the landlord to fix it.

If the problem is from something you can't see or fix, then you'll need to find a way to filter the air in your apartment. There are several ways to do this, but the easiest (and cheapest) is to get an air purifier.

\begin{blockquote}

I live in a 1br apartment in Manhattan, and it consistently smells bad. What is a good way to purify the air in my home?
\end{blockquote}

Air purifiers work by passing air through a filter. They work best when the filter is clean, and you would have to change the filters often, and for some types of filters, they need to be changed monthly.

There are also ionic air purifiers that work by emitting a small electrical charge to air molecules to which they would then attach. This makes them heavier and fall to the ground to be collected by the filter.

Ionic air purifiers don't use filters, but they need to be washed often and the electrical charge will need to be re-applied often.

Some air purifiers combine both filter and ionic technologies.

With that said, I would recommend an ionic air purifier as it is the easiest to maintain.

Introductory paragraph
Main Body
1st point, 2nd point, ..., 5th point
Closure
Concluding paragraph
\end{code}

In each of the above paragraphs, the structure is as follows:

\begin{code}
1st sentence - topic sentence, i.e. the point you are going to make in this paragraph
2nd sentence - supporting your point
3rd sentence - supporting your point
4th sentence - supporting your point
5th sentence - summary of the paragraph
\end{code}

The public healthcare system in the US is mostly run by the federal government.  The largest public healthcare program is Medicare, which provides healthcare to individuals who are 65 years or older, as well as younger individuals with certain disabilities.  The next largest public healthcare program is Medicaid, which provides healthcare to low-income individuals.  The final large public healthcare program is the Veterans' Health Administration, which provides healthcare to veterans.  There are also public healthcare programs at the state level, such as Children's Health Insurance Program (CHIP), which are partially funded by the federal government.

The private healthcare system in the US is made up of a variety of different types of healthcare providers, including hospitals, clinics, and doctor's offices.  In the US, most people get their healthcare through private health insurance companies.  These health insurance companies provide healthcare to individuals through a variety of different plans, such as HMOs (Health Maintenance Organizations), PPOs (Preferred Provider Organizations), and EPOs (Exclusive Provider Organizations).  Most people in the US get their health insurance through their employer, although some individuals also purchase health insurance directly from a health insurance company.

The next most common way that Americans receive healthcare is through the government. Answer: There is no one-size-fits-all answer to this question,

The USA has the most expensive healthcare system in the world, and the most expensive health insurance. And it is not that good.

This is because of government interference in the market.

First, you have to understand the basics of insurance. There are two parties involved in insurance:
\begin{itemize}
\item The insurer. The company who pays you when you make a claim.
\item The insured. The person who buys insurance.
\end{itemize}

If you are in a 100% government run system, then the government is both the insurer and insured. This is the current situation in the UK.

The US government is the insurer of almost all the healthcare in the US, by means of Medicare and Medicaid, and Obamacare. These are government insurance programs for the poor and elderly. The government also subsidises premiums for people who buy private insurance.

The government is both the insurer and insured. This is unsustainable. The insurer is paying the insured, so the insurer must raise premiums to pay for the insured.

People don't like to pay high premiums, so they demand that the government force the insurer to lower them. Thus, a death spiral begins.

Insurance works best when the insured has skin in the game: they must pay part of the premium. This is why insurance is only effective for healthcare when the insured is not the insurer.

The solution to the current problem is to separate the insurer and insured. The government should stop paying for healthcare and take the money it wastes on it, and give the money back to the people. The government should stop forcing people to buy insurance.

Then, people will be able to buy their own insurance, and the insurance companies will be able to set premiums according to risk. The people who are healthy will be able to get cheaper insurance, and the people who are sick can buy insurance for their particular condition.

This is how the insurance market works: insurance is only effective when the insurer is not the insured.

prompt: How can I improve my time management skills?
response_list:
I've had the same problem.

\strong{Solution:}

I make a list of all my tasks for that day, and I write down how much time I think each task will take.  I then plan my day around the time slots that I have.

\strong{Advantage:}

You will have a good idea of how long everything will take.  If you finish early, you can go back and do things you didn't think you'd have time to do.  If you finish late, you'll know what tasks you wereted time on and which ones you didn't.

\strong{Disadvantage:}

You will have to do some research on how much time it really takes to do things.  But, it's worth it.

Comment: You should also have the discipline to stick to that plan.

Comment: +1 for discipline.  I've never been very good with that.

Answer: I have a very similar problem. I recently started using an accounting program called Yodlee MoneyCenter. It allows you to track your time and budget. It allows you to set goals for the amount of time you want to put toward different tasks (work, home, chores, etc). The program will alert you when you have exceeded your budgeted time for a task. I find it very helpful for keeping me on track.

Answer: I've found that the best way to do it is to have a daily plan and a weekly plan, and to do the daily planning first thing in the morning before you go into the office.

You need to decide what you're going to do each day and how much time you'll spend doing it, then plan your whole day accordingly.  It sounds obvious, but I find it's a lot easier to plan your day when you're not under pressure from other people.

When I do it like this, I almost never have projects that run over time because I've already planned for them.  I usually leave myself at least 15 minutes at the end of each day to catch up on anything I've missed.

Answer: I have the very same problem and after years of struggling I have learned that the best solution is to divide my day in chunks. And I mean really small chunks.

I always start my day with a single chunk. It's the chunk that I have to do today. I will decide what task I have to do and what I have to do today.

Then I will give it a time. The time I will use for that task is the same time I use for everything. 10 minutes. 20 maybe.

It's extremely important that you stick to this. If you decide you will spend 10 minutes on a task you have to spend exactly that. Sometimes you'll be done in a few minutes, sometimes you'll be done in 20 minutes. It doesn't matter. You will not do more and you will not do less.

You can only do one thing at a time, so you can't be late on your next task because you were too quick on your previous task.

After you have done your first task you will always have a new chunk.

I know it sounds absurd, but it really works. I have done this for years and I can tell you it's the best solution I have found so far.

Comment: +1 for being specific about time.  I've never been able to stick to a time-based plan very well.

Answer: I've been working on this myself, and so far I've come up with two solutions:
\begin{itemize}
\item \strong{Prioritise.} If you can't get everything done, you need to prioritise. If you don't actually know what's important and what isn't, you need to figure that out.
\item \strong{Timebox.} Give yourself a time limit for a task and stick to it. If you're doing this often, you can set a time limit for the whole day. Don't do more than your timebox limit for a task. If you do, try to shorten the time you spend on other tasks to make up for it.
\end{itemize}

Here are some tips that helped me:
\begin{itemize}
\item Make a to-do list of everything you need to do every day, including personal things like "call mom", "buy groceries" and so on.  It's very easy to forget to do these things, and you should at least make sure you do them every week.
\item Break down your to-do list into smaller tasks.  "Clean room" is a big task that might take hours.  "Tidy up your clothes" would be a smaller task.  "Clean the floor" would be a smaller task.  "Do the dishes" would be a smaller task.  In other words, you want to break down large tasks into smaller tasks.
\item Try to do the smaller tasks first, and the bigger tasks later.  It's easier to get a lot of small tasks done than a couple big ones.
\item Work on multiple tasks at once.  When you're waiting for something to finish, work on other things.  For example, if you're waiting for your computer to boot up, you can be working on your to-do list.
\item Plan ahead.  If you know you're going to be busy one day, do as much as possible the day before.  If you know you're going to be busy one week, do as much as possible that week.
\item Try to organize your time so that you're not too busy on certain days.  For example, if you know you're going to have a free day, you can work on bigger tasks that day.
\item When you're working on a task, try to think of ways to make it more efficient.  For example, can you batch-process multiple files instead of processing one file at a time?  Can you automate some tasks?
\item If you're feeling overwhelmed, take a break.  Go for a walk, listen to some music, watch a movie, read a book, etc.  Do whatever relaxes you.  You'll be more productive when you come back.
\item Try to avoid multitasking.  It might seem like the best way to get things done, but it's actually very inefficient.  You'll get more done if you focus on one task at a time.
\end{itemize}

I've been using a combination of tools and techniques to manage my time better.

Foremost, I use [TickTick](https://www.ticktick.com/) to keep track of my tasks and make sure I'm on schedule. I've found that having a central place to track my tasks and deadlines helps me stay organized and make sure I'm using my time effectively.

In addition to using TickTick, I also make use of the Pomodoro Technique to help me stay focused and on track. This involves breaking up my work into 25-minute chunks, with a 5-minute break in between each one. This helps me stay focused and avoid distractions, and also provides a sense of accomplishment as I complete each task.

Finally, I make sure to take breaks throughout the day to help me stay energized and focused. I find that taking a few minutes to step away from my work and do something else helps me come back to my tasks with a fresh perspective and renewed energy.

Overall, using a combination of tools and techniques has helped me manage my time better and get more done in less time. I hope this helps!

I'm going to offer a slightly different approach.

I've found that the time management techniques I learned in college, and from a couple of books on the subject, worked well for me for a while.  But eventually I decided that they were too prescriptive, and didn't fit my work patterns.  I found that I worked better under pressure, and that I was much more productive (and happier) when I just let myself work on whatever needed to be done, rather than trying to force myself to do things in a certain order.  I also found that trying to schedule everything was a bit overwhelming.

If you're not a very organized person (as I am not), maybe you could just do one thing at a time, and let the rest wait.  I don't think you need to be very organized to do this, but it helps if you can keep track of what you've done.  So you make a list, and you do whatever's easiest for you, and then you cross it off the list.  By the way, when you're done with something, you should always take a minute to decide which of the things you haven't done is the easiest and most meaningful thing to do next.  If there's more than one, just pick one.  And while you're doing that one thing, you should think about what you're going to do next.  That way you can decide in advance what the easiest thing to do next is.

When you're done with that, you should think about which of the things you haven't done is the easiest and most meaningful thing to do next.  If there's more than one, just pick one.

And so on.  The reason this works is that you're always working on the easiest thing you can do right now, so you're not spending a lot of time on things that are too hard for you.  And you're always working on the thing that's most meaningful to you right now, so you're not spending a lot of time on things that aren't meaningful to you.  And you're not trying to force yourself to do things in a certain order, which is really distracting, and it wastes time and makes you unhappy.

There's a lot of things I want to do, but I don't want to do them all right now.  So I keep them all in mind, and I do what I can when I can.  And I'm always thinking about what I can do next.  If I don't have anything else to do, I'll go back and do the next thing on my list.  But sometimes I'll think of something else that's more meaningful to me, and I'll do that instead.  That way, I'm always doing the thing that's most meaningful to me right now.

That's what I do.  It's not really a time management technique, it's just a way to get things done.  I find that I'm much more productive, and happier, when I let myself work on whatever I feel like working on right now, and when I don't force myself to do things in a certain order.  I also find that I'm much less stressed out when I don't have to force myself to do things in a certain order, and I feel like I have more control over my life.

You'll be amazed at how much more quickly you can get things done if you focus on one thing at a time.

If you can't focus on one thing, then you're just switching between tasks without actually doing anything.

You can't multitask.  You can only task switch, which is much less effective.

Answer: I'm with the others.  Focus on one thing at a time.  That's the best way to get it done.

One thing that I've found to help is to keep a list of things that I need to do.  I just have a text file in my home folder called 'Things to do.'  It's got a list of things that I need to do, and I try to prioritize them.

When I get up in the morning, I look at the list.  I decide what the highest priority tasks are.  I start with those.  I also try to balance my list.  If I'm spending too much time on one type of item, I try to switch to something else.

It's good to keep a list.  I use a text file, but you can use any format.

Answer: I'll second the idea of making a daily todo list.  It's amazing how much I get done when I prioritize my day.  I tend to do things in the order of how important they are.  The stuff that I've been putting off for weeks sometimes gets done in a day.

Also, I don't go on the internet before doing my daily work.  That's my reward.  As soon as I finish my work for the day I spend an hour or so on the internet.  I might have an extra 20 min here and there, but I don't spend any significant amount of time on the internet until I've done my work for the day.

Answer: Make a list of what you need to do.  Make a list of things to do in the morning (get some exercise, fix breakfast, get dressed, etc).  Make a list of things to do during the work day (make calls, send emails, etc) and make a list for the evening (go home, make dinner, do housework, etc).  If you're like me, you'll get more done in a day if you have a plan.

Comment: I like this because it doesn't say "Don't get distracted".  It simply states that you should make a list of what you need to do (in other words, be sure you know what you need to do, and make a list).  If you know what you need to do, and you don't do it, then you would be wasting time.

Answer: The best way is to make a list of things you need to do in the next 24 hours, and then go through it, and do it one-by-one. It's important to keep this list handy, and go through it every 30 minutes or so.

Comment: I just started this, and it's amazing at how much I get done.

prompt: What are the most effective ways to deal with stress?
response_list:
\begin{itemize}
\item Go to bed early. Sleep well.
\item Exercise.
\item Meditate.
\item Eat well.
\item Make sure to do things you love doing.
\end{itemize}

Comment: +1 for the last.

Answer: I think the point in the first paragraph is that you, like everyone else, don't have control over your success and you can't do anything about it.

I think that's why I sometimes try to avoid success, because I am unsure what it is I really want.

Comment: I agree with that to a certain extent. However, I think it's better to try to avoid failure than success. To me, failure is a much more uncomfortable feeling.

Answer: The truth is, you're not in control. You're not in control of your success, your achievements, your failures. You're not in control of anything.

So why not just go with this flow? Why not just stop trying to control things? What's the point?

If you want to, give up. Give up on success, on achievement, on failure. Give up on trying to be in control.

But if you don't want to, then start doing some of that. Do a little bit of giving up, and see how it feels. Notice what happens.

And one more thing: when you feel like you're in control, when you're trying to "win" and "succeed" and "achieve", and you're really in control of nothing, you're still in control of something. You're in control of one thing: your suffering.

Answer: If I had to guess, the author is saying that we are not in control of our success.  It is possible to work hard and achieve nothing, and it is possible to work very little and achieve everything.  We always think that we are in control, but we aren't.

Comment: I think he's hinting that we all have a tendency to think that we've got it under control, that we are in control, but we aren't. In the grand scheme of things, not even our success is ours to control.

Answer: The author is trying to explain that no matter how much you work or how 'hard' you work, you cannot control your success, your achievements or your failures.

He is actually asking you to give up and not to try to control things.

Talk about it.  Don't bury your feelings.  Talk to your friends, family, spouse, counselors, etc.  You have to get your feelings out.  Then, figure out what is causing the stress, and try to eliminate it.  Then, try to relax.  Relaxing, for me, means watching a movie, listening to music (with headphones on), or playing a video game.

Comment: I have trouble relaxing too.  But, watching a movie is very easy for me.  I can't stop thinking about my stress, but I can relax my body.  It's like the two are uncoupled.

Answer: Find something that you enjoy and put all your effort into it. I have found that when I am learning new things, I get great enjoyment out of it. I am not so focused on the end result as much as I am the process.

Answer: I've found that the best way to deal with stress is to recognize it and then let it go.

I've found that the best way to recognize it is by taking some time to think about it.  Sit down, close your eyes, and just let thoughts flow through your head.  At first this is difficult, but it gets easier with practice.  Eventually, if you continue to practice, you will start to recognize when stress hits you, and you will be able to recognize the source of it.

Once you've identified the source of the stress, you can then begin to deal with it.  The best way to deal with it is to recognize it, and then let it go.  Sometimes it's hard to let go of negative things, but it's important to do.  I've found that the best thing to do is to just let it flow through me, and then let it go.  Letting go can be very difficult, but with practice it gets easier.  Just remember that all things come to an end.

prompt: How can I increase my productivity while working from home?
response_list:
The first step is to understand how you work best. Understand your own habits and what makes you most productive. For example, are you better working in a quiet environment, with a little bit of background noise, or with music playing? Do you work best with a blank wall (like an office wall) or with something on the wall to focus on?

If you find ways to work best, then you can use those to your advantage. For example, if background noise works best for you, then you can work in a coffee shop or near the kitchen where there is a constant background noise. And if you work best with a wall to focus on, then you can put a bulletin board up in your office to keep your mind focused on what the bulletin board is showing.

Answer: I'd like to provide another point of view, based on my own experience, which I think is a helpful one for a lot of people.

I've found that, when working from home, one of the biggest productivity kills is the lack of routine.

For example, if you're used to working in an office, it's very likely that you have some sort of routine established. You probably know how to get to work, where to park, what to do when you get there, etc. This is a routine you've established over time, and it helps to get you in the right "headspace" to work.

When you work from home, you're missing out on a big chunk of that routine. You don't have to wear a suit to work anymore, you don't have to get up early to catch your bus, etc. All of these things help to establish a routine, and when you're missing them, you're missing out on a big part of what helps you get into "work" mode.

So what I've done is that, while I'm at home, I try to establish my own routine. Even if it's a very small one. For example, I'll get up at the same time as I would if I was going to work, and I'll get myself dressed. I'll then make coffee and breakfast, as I would if I was going to work.

Then, when I start working, I'll work in the same spot as I would in an office. This helps to establish a routine for me, and it helps me to get into "work" mode.

I hope this helps!

Comment: I would add - don't stay in your pajamas. Get dressed for work like you would if you were going to an office. That will help you mentally separate the two spaces.

I have a 2 year old and I've been working from home for 5 years. I have a strict schedule for myself that I follow and a routine for my son.
\begin{itemize}
\item I get up at 6:00am and make a pot of coffee.
\item I put my son down for his nap around 6:45am.
\item I have breakfast and respond to emails between 7:00am and 8:00am.
\item I work from 8:00am to 1:00pm with a 1 hour lunch break daily.
\item I have another pot of coffee and get my son out of bed around 1:00pm.
\item I play with my son for an hour or so and then I get back to work from 1:30pm to 6:00pm.
\item I put my son to bed and have dinner around 6:30pm.
\item I work from 7:00pm until 11:00pm.
\item I have another pot of coffee and read or watch a movie until I pass out around 11:30pm.
\end{itemize}

I love having my own schedule and I enjoy spending time with my son.

Comment: I love this answer, and I've been doing this for a few months. I think I get a ton done with this routine!

Answer: I've been working from home for 6 years, and have 2 kids.

I've found that I'm more productive when I get up early and get some work done before the kids are awake. Then I have the rest of my day free to do what I want.

I've found that it's easier to get up early when I have everything ready for me the night before when I get home.
\begin{itemize}
\item Clothes
\item Breakfast
\item Lunch
\item Snacks
\item Water bottle
\item Laptop
\item Keys
\end{itemize}

That way when I get up, I just have to get dressed and go!

Comment: I've found the same thing.  I get up at 7:00am every day.  I get my coffee, check email, update my to-do list, then get my son up around 8:30am and take him to daycare.  I work until I pick him up around 5:00pm.  He goes down for bed around 7:00pm and I work until 9:00pm.

Answer: I've been working from home for 2 years now with a 2-year-old and a 6-year-old.

I find that the most important thing is to be flexible about the schedule.

For example, you may have planned on working from 11:00 AM to 3:00 PM, but if your son is throwing a tantrum at 11:30 and it doesn't look like you'll get any work done in the next two hours, you might as well go do something fun, take a walk, or go to the park with your wife.

Then when you come back, you'll usually be more productive than if you had stayed home and tried to work.

This is especially true for programming, which is a very mental activity, and which doesn't really require that much concentration.

It is not like you have to be sitting at the computer for hours on end to get anything done.

Comment: I agree with you. I've found that if I spend two hours at home working and I don't accomplish anything, I just get frustrated and then I'm not very productive the rest of the day.
