It's simply gravity and the fact that the air pressure is lower at the top of your esophagus than at the bottom (due to it being open to the atmosphere).

There are two ways to regurgitate food back up:

1) The food is still in the esophagus, so it just comes back up.

2) The food has gone into the stomach, so the stomach has to excrete it.

In case 2), the stomach has to use the same muscles that push food down to push food back up. However, food is normally pushed down by the esophagus's own muscles. At the top of the esophagus, where the muscles are, the food is pushed up into the stomach (by gravity) and the stomach doesn't have to help.

Having learned that, you may now ask a more interesting question: how does the stomach know not to push food down when it is being pushed up?

Answer: If someone doesn't know about gravity it's difficult to get an intuitive grasp of how it works.

The best way to think of gravity is as a tension between two masses.  When you drop something it's the tension between the earth and the thing you dropped that pulls the thing down.  When you push something up it's the tension between the thing you pushed up and the thing you pushed it up with that has to be overcome.

And I think it's easier to understand with an analogy.  When you lift a car off the ground it's the tension between the ground and the car that pulls the car up.  When you push a car it's the tension between the car and the ground that you push against.

So when you eat, the food is pushed down by the tension between it and the stomach.  When you vomit, it's the tension between the stomach and the outside world that pushes the food up through your esophagus.

Answer: Think of it this way:

When you are eating, the food is pushed down by the muscles in your esophagus. When you are vomiting, the food is pushed up by the muscles in your esophagus.

Answer: The answer is that the muscles in your esophagus are contracting and relaxing to move things up and down. When the muscles are contracting, they are pushing the food up. When they are relaxing, they are allowing the food to move down.

prompt: How do noise cancelling headphones/earphones work?
response_list:

Answer: Just a quick explanation:

Noise cancelling headphones are just a headphone with a microphone inside. The microphone picks up the noise, the headphone plays the noise, and in the end, the noise cancelling headphones don't make you hear any noise when you play the noise.

I don't know about how noise cancelling headphones work, but I do know that they act as a microphone that captures the noise and then plays an inverted copy of the noise that cancels it out.  You can have a similar effect by using earplugs and a digital sound processor that can generate inverted signals.

Answer: The basic idea is that you record the noise and feed it back into the headphones to cancel it out.

You can see more detail in the Wikipedia article

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_noise_control

The headphones don't work like a microphone, they are designed to be sensitive to the noise that you want to cancell and then amplify the noise to the same level as the original noise.

You can try a similar effect with some simple speakers and a microphone.  Record the noise and then amplify the noise and play it back.

Answer: Microphones are really sensitive and can't be placed everywhere, so, you'd imagine that you'd need to record the noise and then play it back to cancel it out. But this wouldn't work, as it'd be too quiet to cancel out the real noise with the inverted noise.

So, the headphones themselves are basically mini microphones that pick up the noise, and then invert it, and play that back in the headphones.

If you've ever had a mic and used a mic booster, it's the same principle.

Answer: \begin{itemize}
\item A microphone
\item A speaker
\item An amplifier
\item A processor
\end{itemize}

If you have all of these, you can make a device that will cancel out noise.

You first of all record the noise using the microphone. This noise is then amplified and played through the speaker. The sound waves from the speaker then cancel out the sound waves from the noise you wanted to cancel.

\strong{First}, they do not cancel noise. They reduce noise by a certain amount.

\strong{Second}, they reduce noise by using two microphones, one in each ear (or a microphone on each side of your head, depending on the model).

The microphones are always on. When there is no noise, they produce no sound. However, when noise passes through them, they detect it, and produce an equal amount of "anti-noise" on the other side.

The "anti-noise" is the same sound as the noise, but with its amplitude inverted. So if it were a car horn, the "anti-noise" would be a car horn in reverse.

This is because the anti-noise is the anti-phase of the noise. The amplitude of the anti-noise is the negative of the amplitude of the noise.

\strong{Third}, noise cancellation is not done by the headphones, but is done by the electronics in the headphone jack.

Comment: The anti-noise is not always the same amplitude, but the opposite. The amplitude of the anti-noise is the negative of the noise.

Comment: @RogerRowland - I have added a paragraph about the amplitude of anti-noise.

Comment: @RogerRowland That's not true. Some noise cancellation systems invert the phase and double the amplitude. This results in a louder anti-noise, which can be very advantageous.

The basic idea is that they have two microphones.  One is the microphone you would typically use, and the other is a noise microphone.  The noise microphone measures the ambient noise and it generates a reverse signal of the ambient noise.  Then they combine the signal of the ambient noise and the signal of the microphone, and then they send the cancelled signal to your ears.

I think most researchers agree that for some people, sexual orientation is very strongly innate, but for others it may be more influenced by social factors. [Sexual Orientation, Gender Identity and Brain Structure in Adults by James, et al. (2013)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/23471682)

[Brain Imaging and Sexual Orientation by Bailey, et al. (2003)](http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/12822916)

These papers and others like them also point to evidence that sexual orientation is strongly influenced by social factors.  Although the research isn't conclusive, it's safe to say that if you are raised in a culture that is highly heterosexual (like the US), you will probably exhibit more heterosexual behavior than if you were raised in a culture that is highly homosexual.  This is why researchers sometimes use twin studies to try to isolate the genetic component of sexual orientation.  If identical twins are raised in the same household, they should have very similar sexual orientation. This is an option for a hybrid because the exhaust is already there.  But if you're starting from scratch, you're going to have a lot of trouble just getting a hybrid working.

One of the main problems is that the exhaust is low pressure.  In order to get useful power, you'd have to use a Rankine cycle engine.  The problem with a Rankine cycle engine is that you have to build a separate low pressure system to capture that exhaust.  So you have to have a separate engine, and a separate cooling system, and a separate low pressure system to capture the exhaust.

You could use a turbine, but it would have to be very small.  A turbine that is even 1/10th the size of the engine is going to produce only a fraction of the power.  So you'd end up with a very inefficient system, and a very small motor.  If you're starting with a low power motor, it's very hard to get it to produce enough power to run.

There is another problem with a Rankine cycle engine.  While a Rankine cycle engine is very efficient at low power, it is not nearly as efficient as a regular car engine.  You're going to waste a lot of fuel just to produce the energy to run the engine.

An officer's police psychologist is the first person to go to if the officer is having difficulty dealing with trauma.  There is also a confidential hotline available to all police officers and their family members 24 hours a day.  (I used to work there.)

The officer's chaplain is also available to talk about anything and everything, and that includes trauma.

The department also has a lot of other resources available.  The first one is the Peer Support Team, which is made up of officers who have been through a 40 hour course in dealing with trauma.  They know how police officers work and can help in many ways.

The department also has a "Wellness Program" which includes a monthly newsletter with articles on a variety of topics including dealing with trauma.  They have a yearly Wellness Conference for police employees, and a yearly Wellness Retreat for police officers and their families.  They also have a Wellness Center available to all employees.  It is a room with a couch, a coffee pot and a refrigerator, and it is a place where people can go to relax and get away from work for a few minutes.

The department also offers a variety of classes to help deal with trauma.  They have a monthly "Wellness Day", which is a day where all employees can go to a variety of classes to help them deal with stress and trauma.  They also have a "Stress Management" class that they offer to new officers, which helps officers deal with stress and trauma.  And they also have a "Cop Talk" class which helps police officers deal with trauma as well as other issues.

Perhaps you're implying that the majority of trauma is manageable, and that's probably true, but I've known police officers who have gone through a lot of traumatic experiences and still haven't sought help.  I think that's the point the OP is trying to make.

Comment: @Richard:  I don't think I made that point.  I made the point that there are many more police officers who don't need help with trauma than those who do.  I don't think it's possible to be in police work without experiencing trauma.  And you're right that I didn't say many of the traumas were manageable.  Some are not.  I said that those who need help have a variety of ways they can get help.  I'm sure the OP knows that.

Answer: I'm not sure that I can speak for police officers, but I can speak for the military. In basic training, we were given a series of written and verbal tests to determine if we were candidates for a "psych" eval. If we passed, that meant that we did not show any signs of "psychotic episodes". If we got sent to the psych, that meant we were candidates for having psychotic episodes (schizophrenia, PTSD, etc).

I was sent to the psych as a candidate, and during my evaluation, I was told that 70% of the population of the United States is candidates for having psychotic episodes. I was told that I was not more likely to have a psychotic episode than anyone else; I was just as likely as the next guy.

The point is, there's no single "thing" that makes a person more likely to be a victim of PTSD than the next.

Now, I'm not trying to say that there's no difference between a police officer and a normal civilian, but I am trying to say that everyone is a candidate. You can be one of the 30% that never gets PTSD, or one of the 70% that is a candidate. If you're a candidate, you might never get PTSD, you might get it, or you might get it and recover.

\section{Training}

I'm not a detective, but I am a firefighter.  I have seen dead bodies, and I have seen them mutilated, and it was extremely disturbing.  However, I've seen it so many times that it is part of my job.  While I do not like it, I can do it, and I can do it effectively.

The same is true for homicide detectives.  They have a certain level of training that helps them deal with things that most people cannot.  There are classes on how to deal with dead bodies, how to maintain composure when dealing with the family of the victim, and other training courses.  It's not easy, but it is possible.

I have seen a dead body maybe a dozen times in my career, and I have seen them in all kinds of states.  I have seen a burned body, a mutilated body, and a body that had been frozen.  I have seen a body that was decapitated and one that had a head that was missing.  No matter what I saw, I was able to deal with it.  I was able to deal with it, and I was able to deal with it effectively.

While I do not like seeing dead bodies, I can do it, and I can do it effectively.

If you are exposed to something often enough, you will become used to it.  While I am not a detective, I am a firefighter. While I do not like it, I can do it, and I can do it effectively.

I have known many homicide detectives from various police departments - and they do not stay sane. Not by a long shot. Most of them are not sane to begin with.

In order to be a homicide detective, you must have a very strong stomach, a very strong will, and the ability to compartmentalise everything. You must be able to see a dead body, pick up the weapon that killed the victim, and then go back to work without much thought of what it is you just saw. You must be able to understand that the victim doesn't matter, and you must be able to focus on the case and the perpetrator.

This is a very bad job for most people. I would not recommend it to anyone.

\em{The Rain}

\em{Author: [Froggy](https://scifi.stackexchange.com/users/112960/froggy)}

The rain had been falling for hours. It was always raining in that godforsaken city, it was as if the gods were mad at it for the misdeeds of the humans who lived there. It was a never-ending cycle. The rain would fall all day, into the night, and then it would continue the next day. Never halting. Never ending.

The girl didn't mind the rain, but she didn't like the cold. She'd been cold for as long as she could remember, and at first, she'd thought it was all because of the rain. But now, she wasn't even sure if it was the rain, or just the city itself.

She had been walking since the sun had risen. She had a vague idea of where she was going, but it wasn't specific. She just felt like she needed to get somewhere, and she had no idea where it was. She didn't know why, she just knew she needed to be somewhere else. Somewhere warm. Somewhere dry.

She was tired, hungry, and thirsty. She'd been out in the rain for so long that she could barely remember how it felt to be dry. The rain had soaked through her clothes, and she was shivering.

She'd been walking for hours, but she still had no idea where she was. She didn't even know if she was going in the right direction. But she kept walking, because there was nothing else to do.

Suddenly, she heard a sound. It was a low, growling sound. She stopped and looked around, but she couldn't see anything. Then, she heard it again. It was coming from the alley to her left.

She slowly walked into the alley. As she did, she noticed a small, black shape in the shadows. She squinted her eyes to get a better look, and she saw that it was a puppy.

But this wasn't just any puppy. This puppy was different. It had three heads, and it was growling at her.

She stepped back, and the puppy took a step forward. It growled again, and then it took another step forward. The girl was starting to get scared. She didn't know what to do.

Then she saw it. In the shadows, in the alley, was a small, wooden door. She didn't know what was behind the door, but she knew it was better than facing the puppy.

She slowly walked towards the door, and the puppy followed her. She reached out and touched the door handle, and it swung open.

The girl stepped inside, and the puppy followed her. She closed the door behind her, and the puppy stopped growling.

The girl stood there for a moment, catching her breath. She was cold, wet, and tired. She didn't know what to do.

Then, she heard a voice. It was a woman's voice, and it was coming from somewhere inside the house. The girl walked towards the voice, and she found herself in a small, cozy living room.

The woman was sitting in a chair by the fireplace. She was an old woman, with a kind face.

"Hello," said the woman. "Who are you?"

"I'm... I'm not sure," said the girl. "I just... I just found this puppy in the rain. It's different. It has three heads."

The woman smiled. "I know what you mean. This is my home, and this is my puppy. His name is Cerberus."

"Cerberus?" said the girl. "That's the name of the three-headed dog from Greek mythology."

"Yes, it is," said the woman. "He's a very special puppy. He's been with me for many years."

The girl looked at Cerberus. He was a beautiful dog, with black fur and three white heads. She couldn't help but smile.

"Thank you for taking me in," she said. "I was cold and wet, and I didn't know where to go."

The woman smiled. "You're welcome. Now, why don't you get warmed up by the fire?"

When I was a kid, I used to have a pet dog. It was a three-headed mutt, and I named it Cerberus. I was very young at the time, and I didn't know much about Greek mythology, so I thought it was a funny name. I was pretty sure that it was just a normal dog, and I didn't think much about it.

One day, I was walking Cerberus around the neighborhood when we came across a strange man. He was dressed all in black, and he had a dark, hooded cloak covering his face. He seemed very mysterious, and I was a bit scared of him. He asked me if I knew where he could find a three-headed dog. I was a bit hesitant to answer, but I eventually told him that I had one.

The man thanked me and told me that he was looking for Cerberus because he was a Greek god and he needed Cerberus to guard the underworld. I was a bit confused, but I didn't question it. The man asked if he could take Cerberus with him, and I agreed. I was a bit sad to see my beloved pet go, but I knew that it was for the best.

The man took Cerberus and vanished into thin air. I was left standing there, wondering what had just happened. It was a bit unsettling, but I eventually forgot about it and went on with my life. I still miss my three-headed dog to this day.

prompt: Can planets orbit twin star systems?
response_list:
Yes, of course planets can orbit twin star systems.

There are a couple of ways that it can happen:
\begin{itemize}
\item Most commonly, a planet can orbit a single star of a binary star system. The planet will orbit the single star and the single star will orbit the other star.
\item A planet can orbit a binary star system in the same way that a planet can orbit a single star.
\end{itemize}

Comment: Do you have any references for this?

Comment: I'd be pretty certain that #1 is true, but #2 seems unlikely to me--if you're in the same orbit as one star, you're not in the same orbit as the other one.  Can you provide a reference for #2?

Comment: @Rod: you're right. I've edited my post.

Yes.  See this [Wikipedia article](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Circumbinary_planet)

Comment: That's a good answer.  Thank you.

Yes, planets can orbit around twin star systems. It's even more likely than single star systems, because a large star tends to have a larger planetary orbit.

The best example is the [Alpha Centauri system](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpha_Centauri#Alpha_Centauri_A-B_system), which is a binary star, and the planet Proxima Centauri b, which is in orbit around the third star in the system, Proxima Centauri.

Another example is the [Tau Boötis system](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tau_Bo%C3%B6tis), which has at least two planets in orbit around the twin star system, Tau Boötis A and B.

Comment: This is great. However, I just read that the Alpha Centauri system is not actually a binary star, as one of the stars is a red dwarf. It has no companion star. However, it is located very close to a binary star system, Alpha Centauri AB. I am not sure if this changes anything.

Comment: @user176587 The Alpha Centauri system is a binary star system, even though one of the stars is a red dwarf. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpha_Centauri#Alpha_Centauri_AB_system. The red dwarf is very close to the binary star system, but it is not part of it.

Comment: It's a bit more complicated than that, actually. Alpha Centauri AB is a binary star, but the system is actually a triple star with Proxima Centauri, an M dwarf.  See: [Wikipedia: Alpha Centauri](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpha_Centauri) and [Wikipedia: Alpha Centauri A](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alpha_Centauri_A)

Comment: @Luaan I meant the binary star system, not the whole system. The planet is in orbit around the binary star system, not the triple star system.

Comment: @DorianKoss: That's true, but there's some confusion.  The star system is "Alpha Centauri", but the binary star is "Alpha Centauri AB", which is clearly written in the Wikipedia article you linked to. prompt: If ADHD is caused by having a lower baseline dopamine level, why is it so hard to diagnose? Can't we just measure dopamine levels?
response_list:
The short answer is, no, it can't be measured directly. This is because it is a dynamic process, which is regulated by both genetic and environmental factors.

The longer answer, as I discuss in [The Neuroscience of ADHD](https://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/com/B00LH77QY0), is that dopamine is a [neurotransmitter](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neurotransmitter), which means that it is released by one neuron and causes a change in the electrical state of another neuron. Dopamine is released from a [synaptic vesicle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synaptic_vesicle) in the terminal buttons of the neuron, and it is not free in the extracellular fluid. In addition, dopamine is metabolized by the enzyme [catechol-O-methyltransferase](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Catechol-O-methyltransferase), commonly abbreviated as COMT. This enzyme degrades dopamine (in addition to serotonin and norepinephrine) by converting it to 3-methoxytyramine.

When dopamine is released, it binds to the [D1](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dopamine_receptor) and [D2](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dopamine_receptor) receptors. The D1 receptors are located on G protein-coupled receptors, and the D2 receptors are on G protein-coupled receptors and [ion channels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion_channel). In any case, the effects of dopamine on these receptors are to increase the electrical excitation of the cell. The increased electrical excitation of the cell is what causes the effects of dopamine on the brain.

Answer: It's a good question, and one that's been around for a long time. In fact, there's a famous story about how it took a lot of work to convince Euclid that the number $\pi$ is infinite.

In short, it's because $\pi$ cannot be written as a fraction of two integers. If you try to do so, you'll get a number that's smaller than $\pi$ - like $355/113$, which is an approximation that's about $2.5\%$ off.

If you find a number that's smaller than $\pi$, but you claim it's equal to $\pi$, then you've just proven that all numbers are finite.

In fact, the whole field of mathematics is based on the idea that numbers are infinite. Consider the Pythagorean Theorem. If you have a triangle with sides $3$, $4$, and $5$, then the area of the triangle is $3\times 4\times 5 = 60$.

But if you assume that all numbers are finite, then the Pythagorean Theorem becomes meaningless. Why? Because you can always find an integer solution to the equation $x^2+y^2=z^2$. For example, $1^2+1^2=2^2$, so $1$ is a solution to the equation. But what about $2^2+1^2=3^2$? That's also a solution. And $3^2+2^2=5^2$ is also a solution.

You can keep doing this forever. You can always find an integer solution to the equation $x^2+y^2=z^2$.

In fact, you can do the same thing with any equation. You can always find an integer solution to the equation $x^2+y^2=z^2$.

But if you assume that all numbers are infinite, then the Pythagorean Theorem becomes meaningful again.

Imagine you have a sequence of real numbers $a,b,c,d,e,f,g,h,...$ such that $a,b,c,d,e$ are all distinct, and the difference between $a$ and $b$ is the same as the difference between $c$ and $d$ and so on.

Then for each $n$ we have that $a+(n-1)b=c$, $a+nb=d$, $a+(n-1)d=e$, $a+nd=f$, $a+(n-1)f=g$, $a+ng=h$, ...

Now, let's take for instance $g=h$ and $g+h=i$

Now, we want to prove that $a+(n-1)h = i$

\begin{align}
a+(n-1)h &= a+(n-1)(g+h)\\
&= a+ng+nh\\
&= a+ng+g+h\\
&= c+d\\
&= i
\end{align}

Thus, by the principle of mathematical induction, we can extend this to any $n$ to obtain that

$$a+(n-1)h = i$$

Now, to prove that there are infinitely many terms, just notice that $a$ is fixed and that $a+(n-1)h=i$ implies that $h=i-a$ and that $h$ is fixed.

Thus, we have infinitely many elements in our sequence.

There are two answers to this.

\strong{1) Mathematical proof}

You can prove that there is no end to pi. Basically, you construct a sequence of numbers:
$$a_0 = 3, a_1 = \frac{1}{5}, a_2 = \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{1}{5}, a_3 = \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{1}{5} \cdot \frac{1}{5}, \ldots$$

Then you notice that each term of this sequence is getting closer and closer to $\pi$.

Now, if it were to eventually stop, then the last term of this sequence would equal $\pi$.

But the last term of the sequence is only an approximation to $\pi$.

So, we conclude that there is no end to pi.

\strong{2) Experimental evidence}

You can also do a simple experiment.

Take a square with sides of length $1$.

Split that square into $n$ smaller squares of side length $\frac{1}{n}$.

Keep doing this, and you'll end up with an infinite amount of squares.

Now, take the distance from the center of the square to the perimeter of the square.

This distance is $2 \pi$.

But, if you keep splitting the square into smaller and smaller squares, this distance gets closer and closer to $2 \pi$.

So, we conclude that the number of squares you need to split the square into to get $2 \pi$ is going to be infinite.

prompt: How come the space station needs to fire a rocket regularly to stay in orbit, but dangerous space junk can stay up there indefinitely?
response_list:
\begin{blockquote}
How come the space station needs to fire a rocket regularly to stay in orbit, but dangerous space junk can stay up there indefinitely?
\end{blockquote}

It doesn't.

The [space station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Space_Station) is only one of many objects in Earth orbit.  It has to be boosted to a higher orbit whenever it is about to collide with other objects.  It is not boosted to a higher orbit just because it is about to stay up there forever.

As to the dangerous space junk, not every piece of it is at a stable orbit.  The Earth's atmosphere is not a uniform "wall" separating space from the Earth.  Instead, it is a thin layer of gas with a density that falls off with altitude.  As a result, even if you have a stable orbit at a low altitude, it is possible to eventually lose the orbit and fall back to Earth.  The International Space Station orbits at an altitude of about 400 kilometres.  However, [objects](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_orbiting_artificial_satellites_of_the_Soviet_Union_and_Russia) orbiting at altitudes of less than 100 kilometres are subject to re-entry within a few decades.  The [Hubble Space Telescope](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hubble_Space_Telescope) orbits at an altitude of about 550 kilometres.  It is currently subject to re-entry in about 2028.  [Skylab](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Skylab), which orbited at an altitude of about 430 kilometres, re-entered the atmosphere in 1979.  Other objects, such as the [debris from a 2007 Chinese rocket](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2007_Chinese_anti-satellite_missile_test), are subject to re-entry at an altitude of 200 kilometres.

Comment: This is a great answer, thanks!  I think it may be interesting to point out that the ISS will probably not be operational forever, so if it were to lose orbit and fall to Earth, it would probably be lost anyway.

Comment: @MatthewRenzi the ISS is planned to be operational for at least another ten years, but I think you are correct that its de-orbit would be inevitable at some point.

Comment: @DaveRenfrew I think it's intended to be operational for about 20 years.  It has already been operational for more than 20 years.  In any case, it is not currently de-orbiting.  It is currently boosting its velocity.  As a result, it is increasing its altitude.  It will stay in orbit as long as it is boosted.  After that, it will eventually fall back to Earth.

The space station is a satellite and needs to stay in orbit. The station needs to stay in orbit because the orbiting object is moving very fast (approximately 17,000 miles per hour) and if it slows it's speed it will come down to earth.

Junk in orbit doesn't need to stay in orbit, it can be left there because it is already in orbit.

Answer: The space station is in orbit.  In order to maintain that orbit, it needs to move along the same path as the Earth's curvature.  This means that its speed has to exactly match the speed that the Earth is rotating at.  If it slows down, it will be slower than the Earth's rotation, and will fall back down to Earth.

If the space station slows down, it will stay in orbit for a little while, but when it eventually falls back down to Earth, it will be moving a lot faster than it needs to, so it will hit the ground hard.

But if you get rid of your junk in orbit, it will just fall back down to Earth.  It can take years to get up to space, but it only takes minutes or hours to fall back down to Earth.

Comment: Well, technically, it will be moving slower than the Earth's rotation, but it's still going to be moving fast enough that it's not going to fall back down to Earth.

Junk objects are not in any particular orbit. They are just floating around. They can stay there for as long as they don't hit anything or get caught by another object's gravity well.

Space station orbits are not necessarily stable.

A space station is a \em{man-made object in space} and is subject to the same forces as any other object in space. Any orbiting object is subject to change due to the following forces:
\begin{itemize}
\item [Gravity](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gravity)
\item [Chemical forces](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chemical_bond)
\item [Electromagnetic forces](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Electromagnetism)
\item [Solar wind](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_wind)
\end{itemize}

The first three of those forces are weak and can be ignored for practical purposes.

The [Solar wind](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_wind) is the most prominent of the forces affecting an orbiting satellite. A solar wind is a flow of electrically charged particles flowing outward from the Sun in all directions.

The Earth's magnetic field deflects the solar wind around the Earth, however this does not prevent the solar wind from exerting a force on objects in space.

\strong{The force exerted by the solar wind is called the [Poynting-Robertson effect](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poynting%E2%80%93Robertson_effect)}

<IMAGE>

The Poynting-Robertson effect is a force that causes an orbiting object to lose altitude and eventually crash into the Earth.

\section{Space Junk}

All objects in space are subject to the Poynting-Robertson effect and will slowly fall to Earth.

However, since the Poynting-Robertson effect is a very small force, it takes a \em{very long time} to cause an object to fall to Earth.

In fact, the Poynting-Robertson effect can be ignored for any object that is on a stable orbit.

\section{Space Station}

Space stations have to maintain their orbit, otherwise they will eventually fall to Earth due to the Poynting-Robertson effect.

\strong{This is exactly the same as any natural satellite orbiting the Earth.}

\section{Summary}

The force exerted by the solar wind is called the [Poynting-Robertson effect](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poynting%E2%80%93Robertson_effect).

This force slowly causes everything in space to fall towards the Earth.

The Poynting-Robertson effect is negligible for any object that is orbiting the Earth on a stable orbit.

Space stations need to maintain their orbit.

Space junk can stay up there indefinitely.

It actually has nothing to do with the fact that "dangerous space junk" is in a higher orbit.  As you correctly point out, that is actually a lower orbit, and the reason is that the space station is in a lower orbit.

When the space shuttle goes up, it goes up to LEO (low earth orbit).  The space station is located in LEO, so it has to be in the same orbit.

If the space station was in geosynchronous orbit (GEO), then it wouldn't need to fire its rockets.  The space station is in LEO because it is easier and cheaper to get there.  A launch from LEO only needs to accelerate to about 7.8 km/s to get to GEO.  A launch from the ground needs to accelerate to 11.2 km/s.

The reason the space station is in LEO is because of the way rockets are designed and built.  The fuel is located on the bottom of the rocket, and you can only carry it in a certain amount of volume due to structural considerations.  LEO orbits are much closer to the ground, so the fuel needed to get there is much smaller.  A rocket in GEO would have to carry enough fuel to get to that orbit, and then expend that fuel to get to GEO.  It is much cheaper to launch a rocket in LEO that is much smaller, but then have to use the fuel in the rocket to get to GEO.

prompt: In the US, onions are the only commodity that can not be traded as a futures contract due to 1958 Onion Futures Act. Why was this restriction not repealed along with other deregulation measures of 80s and 90s? Why was onion seen as different from other commodities?
response_list:
The most recent attempt to repeal the Onion Futures Act was unsuccessful.  [Here is a link to the text of the bill](https://www.congress.gov/bill/116th-congress/house-bill/1787) and here is the [current status](https://www.govtrack.us/congress/bills/116/hr1787/status) of the bill.

The reason this act was put into place is that the onion futures market had been manipulated by large traders.  The original act was put in place in response to a 1955 scandal where the futures markets were manipulated by an individual who controlled 150,000 onions.  The individual sold all of the onions he had in storage and sold futures contracts on the same onions he did not have in storage.  When it came time to deliver on the futures contracts, he could not deliver the onions and the price of onions went down.  The scandal was referred to as the "Texas Onion Scandal."  [Here is a link](https://www.futuresmag.com/2012/06/10/texas-onion-scandal) to an article about the "Texas Onion Scandal."

The act was put into place to prevent further market manipulation.  The act was amended in 1984 and again in 2014.  The 2014 amendment was an attempt to repeal the act.  The bill was introduced in the House in 2014 and the Senate in 2016.  The bill was passed by the House in 2016 but did not pass the Senate.

Comment: Can you cite a source for the assertion that the 1958 act was put into place to prevent manipulation?

Comment: @Nathaniel - I added a link to the text of the bill and another link to the status of the bill.  I also added a link to an article about the Texas Onion Scandal.

The act was not repealed because the Onion Growers of America, Inc. lobbied to keep it in place. This is from [Wikipedia](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Onion_Futures_Act_of_1958):

\begin{blockquote}

The Onion Futures Act of 1958 was passed to keep onions from being
  traded on the Chicago Board of Trade. Onions can have natural
  fluctuations in their supply and demand, making them very risky in
  the commodity market. The act was passed in response to the
  onion-price volatility that occurred in 1954.

One of the main reasons the act was passed was to protect
  consumers by making onions more affordable. In 2010, the
  Onion Futures Act was challenged in court by the largest onion
  growers in the United States and Canada. The group cited the
  1996 Farm Bill, which allowed for the trading of onion futures. In
  October 2010, the U.S. federal court ruled that all existing
  contracts for onion futures were null and void as of January 3,
  2011.

Onions can still be traded on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange,
  however, unlike other futures markets, they are cash settled and
  cannot be delivered physically.
\end{blockquote}

Apparently the growers have more political influence than the traders.

Answer: The Onion Futures Act of 1958 (Pub.L. 85–832, 72 Stat. 1082, enacted September 2, 1958) was passed in response to the onion-price volatility that occurred in 1954. (Wikipedia)

The reason for the act was to protect the consumer. The onion industry was volatile and the act was passed in response to that volatility.

Here is a good article from the Washington Post on why onions are different from other commodities.

https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2013/07/19/why-onions-are-the-only-commodity-you-cant-trade-on-the-chicago-board-of-trade/

There was no market for futures contracts on onions, and there still isn't.  The Act was not repealed because it was not seen as having anything to do with deregulation of commodity markets, which was the goal of the futures markets legislation of the 1980s and 90s.

"Deregulation" in the 1980s and 90s meant deregulation of agricultural commodity markets not futures markets, and no one was demanding that onions be added to the list of commodities that could be traded in futures markets.  [The 1958 Onion Futures Act](https://www.govinfo.gov/app/details/GPO-CITED/GPO-CITED-1958-11-28T00:00:00) "declared that onions are a perishable commodity and that the public interest requires that speculative trading in onions should be restrained and curtailed."  It did not declare onions to be a non-perishable commodity that should be allowed to be traded in futures markets.

The 1958 Onion Futures Act established a [Committee on Onion Futures Trading](https://www.cftc.gov/sites/default/files/idc/files/onion_committee.pdf) that is still in existence.  The Committee is required to meet at least once a year, and it is still meeting.  The 2020 meeting was held via teleconference in April 2020, and the minutes are available [here](https://www.cftc.gov/sites/default/files/idc/files/minutes_of_onion_committee_meeting_4302020.pdf).  The Committee doesn't have anything to do with deregulation of futures markets; it's just a forum where people who are interested in onion futures trading can meet and discuss matters affecting onion futures trading.

[This article](https://www.nass.usda.gov/Statistics_by_State/New_York/Publications/Onion_Futures_Trading.pdf) from the USDA's National Agricultural Statistics Service gives some background on the 1958 Onion Futures Act.

\begin{blockquote}

Onion futures trading, which was never allowed by the Chicago Board of Trade (CBOT), was banned in 1958 by the Onion Futures Act. The act outlawed any futures trading in onions, and also prohibited options trading in onions by any commodity exchange, board of trade, or similar organization.
\end{blockquote}

The [Onion Futures Act](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Onion_Futures_Act) was introduced in 1958 in response to a large number of fraudulent onion futures contracts being issued by the Chicago Board of Trade. It was repealed in 1981, but the Commodity Futures Trading Commission prohibited onion futures trading because of the 1958 act.

The 1958 act also prohibited onion futures trading on other exchanges, but the CFTC has since allowed onion futures trading on other exchanges.

It is because of the [Wickard v. Filburn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wickard_v._Filburn) decision.

\begin{blockquote}

The case was brought about after Roscoe Filburn, a farmer in Ohio, was fined for growing wheat on his own farm for his own use, in violation of the Agricultural Adjustment Act of 1938. The Supreme Court upheld the fine. It is one of the most important cases in the history of the United States. The Court ruled that the Constitution's Commerce Clause gave Congress the power to regulate all economic activity.
\end{blockquote}

In a nutshell, the Commerce Clause gives the Federal government the authority to regulate interstate commerce, including agricultural products. This was the first time that the Court ruled that intrastate activity could be regulated.

The case was brought about because the farmer had grown more wheat than allowed by the law, but had used it all on his own farm. This would have had a negative effect on wheat prices, so the government was able to fine the farmer because of it.

The case is still good law today, and it is impossible to trade onions on the futures market because of it.

The number of keys in the scale comes from the number of tones in an octave.

The number of tones in an octave is a physical property of sound, and is determined by the frequency of the tone.  For a standard A440 tuning, the frequency of an A is 440Hz.  The frequency of the B that is an octave above the A is 880Hz.  The frequency of the C that is an octave above the B is 1760Hz.  And so on...

In the middle of the 18th century, musicians discovered that if you divided the octave into 12 equal parts, the frequency of each of those parts was a ratio of 1:2:4:8:16:32:64:128:256:512:1024:2048.  This ratio is called a just intonation.

(In practice, the frequencies of notes in an A440 octave do not match perfectly these just intonation ratios, but they are pretty close.  The frequencies are determined by the length of the strings and other physical properties of the instrument).

Since 12 is the smallest number of parts that can be divided into a 128:256:512:1024:2048 just intonation ratio, this gives us the 12 notes in the scale.  If you divide the octave into 20 parts, you get 12 more notes, but they are not in a just intonation ratio, and so they aren't considered to be part of the scale.

To get the major and minor scales, you take the notes which are 1:2:3:6:8 away from each other in the scale, and those are the notes of the major scale.  You take the notes which are 1:2:3:4:5:6 away from each other in the scale, and those are the notes of the minor scale.

The [12-Tone Equal Temperament](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/12-Tone_Equal_Temperament) is a scale that is based on the idea that each note in a scale must be the same distance apart from each other.

In the 12-Tone Equal Temperament, there are 12 notes, each 100 cents apart from each other.  A cent is the smallest unit of measurement of pitch, and there are 100 cents in a semitone.  So if you play a note a semitone higher or lower than another note, it will be one cent away from the other note.  The same reasoning applies for the other semitones, and there are 12 of them in the 12-Tone Equal Temperament, each one 100 cents away from each other.

The easiest way to see this is to take a piano and play every note in the scale, going from `C` to `B`, and then back from `B` to `C`.  The distance between each note will be 100 cents.  If you take a piano with a normal keyboard, the distance between each key will be 12 semi-tones, or 1200 cents, which is much too much of a distance between each note.  So if you play all the notes in a row, the whole scale will sound very 'off' and out of tune.  On a piano with a normal keyboard, the scale would go from `C` to `C#` to `D` to `D#` to `E` etc....

The 12-Tone Equal Temperament is used because it is the best compromise of 'musicality' and 'accuracy'.  The 12-Tone Equal Temperament gives every note in the scale the same distance apart, and makes the scale sound 'musical', but it also is accurate enough that if you play the notes in order on a piano, it will sound in tune.

However, the 12-Tone Equal Temperament doesn't give each note an equal amount of 'tension', which is what makes some scales sound more 'musical' than others.  The 12-Tone Equal Temperament is the best compromise because it gives each note in a scale equal distance away from each other, and also gives each note an equal amount of tension.

Also, the 12-TET is very rough on the overtones, which causes many timbres to be less pleasant than they would be with a different tuning.

Here is how I think of it.

You have a scale which is a series of notes arranged in increasing order of pitch. For example, for the key of C this would be the notes C, D, E, F, G, A, B and then back to C.

Each note can be represented by a frequency. The note C, for example, is 261.63Hz. The note D is 293.66Hz and so on.

The notes in a scale can be grouped into two types - major and minor. The major notes have a "happy" feeling to them. The minor notes have a "sad" feeling to them.

The major notes have a frequency which is a multiple of a major interval. In other words, a frequency which is a multiple of a whole number.

The minor notes have a frequency which is a multiple of a minor interval. In other words, a frequency which is a multiple of some number with a fractional part.

So, for example, C is a major note. It has a frequency of 261.63Hz, which is a multiple of 3. (i.e. 3 x 87.21Hz)

D is a minor note. It has a frequency of 293.66Hz, which is a multiple of 4/3. (i.e. 4/3 x 87.21Hz)

The major notes are:
\begin{itemize}
\item C
\item D
\item E
\item F
\item G
\item A
\item B
\end{itemize}

The minor notes are:
\begin{itemize}
\item D
\item E
\item F
\item G
\item A
\item B
\item C
\end{itemize}

You can see that the major notes all have a multiple of 3 as their frequency and the minor notes all have a multiple of 4/3 as their frequency.

So, the scale of C major has the notes C, D, E, F, G, A, B and C.

The scale of D minor has the notes D, E, F, G, A, B, C and D.

The scale of D major has the notes D, E, F#, G, A, B and C#.

The scale of D minor has the notes D, E, F, G, A, B, C and D.

For D major, we have the notes D, E, F#, G, A, B and C#. There are two new notes in the scale - the sharps, F# and C#.

For D minor, we have the notes D, E, F, G, A, B, C and D. There is just one new note in the scale - the flat, B flat.

The scales of different keys have different notes in them. This is why they are different.

The reason I think of it this way is that it helps me to remember the relationship between the different scales. For example, if I know that the scale of D major has the notes D, E, F#, G, A, B and C# I can easily work out what the scale of G major is. (G, A, B, C, D, E and F#)

If you know any music theory, you might be able to work out that the minor scales are just the major scales with the third, sixth and seventh notes flattened. This is a good thing to know because it means you can easily work out the minor scales from the major scales. (e.g. for the key of D major, the minor scale is D minor.)

Hope this helps.

Answer: It's a good question. You are essentially asking why are there 12 tones in the octave. If you are asking why there are 7 major keys and 5 minor keys, then that is a different question.

The answer to the first question is historical. The reason is that in the early days of music, there were only 12 tones in the octave. For instance, in the Middle Ages, the lowest tone was written as C and the highest tone was written as C' (pronounced C prime). They also used 12 tones to the octave to help with singing. That is why we still use C, C#, D, D#, E, F, F#, G, G#, A, A#, and B in modern music.

First, if you're thinking about marriage, the question is really: do you want to get married, or do you want to spend the rest of your life with this person? Because getting married isn't going to make anything better, it's just a piece of paper and a ring. If you're just looking for that, then don't get married. I don't think it will help you any.

Second, if you do want to spend the rest of your life with this person, then you need to know that no matter what you do, this person will never be perfect and that's OK. You are both going to change, things are going to change, and you need to be OK with that. If you can't accept that, then maybe you should just break up.

Third, if you do decide that you want to spend the rest of your life with this person, you need to be very careful about who you marry, because you can't just walk out of a marriage whenever you feel like it. Here's one that will be a good test of your car's abilities:

http://autoclubspeedway.com/

Comment: This is the correct answer! This is what I thought of too but I'm not local to this area so I didn't know if it would be worth the money.

Comment: It's not cheap, but it's a lot of fun!

Comment: Looks like fun.  I've been to a couple of road courses, but none that let you bring your own car (or rent one).  I've been to the speedway a couple of times as well.

Comment: Wow, I didn't even think about the speedway.  I've been there, but never thought about doing this.  I've been to Summit Point, but it is in WV and not in the middle of no where.

Comment: If you want to be a bit further away from the city, there's also Summit Point in WV, and BeaveRun in PA.

Comment: This is the correct answer!

http://www.msregistry.com/

I went to this place a few years ago, it was really fun. It's not a race track, but a huge empty parking lot where you can go as fast as you want inside your car.

They have a few different cars that you can rent from them, or you can bring your own vehicle.

Comment: I went here as well. I would recommend it.

Comment: I drove my own car and it was very cool. If you want to be a bit safer, they have a few different "cars" you can rent. I drove the "go kart" and it was a blast. It will get up to like 70mph in a few seconds.

Answer: I don't know where you live, but the closest thing I can think of to a true "race track" would be a place like [Summit Point Motorsports Park](http://www.summitpoint-raceway.com/) in West Virginia.  It's a large track with a mixture of turns and straight-aways.  They do have a couple of "go-cart" style cars that you can rent, but they're not very fast.  They also have "instructor" cars that they use to teach you how to drive the track in a safe, controlled manner.

Comment: That's way too much for me. I'm not even sure if I want to drive 50 mph yet. I just need a place where I can go to learn to drive my own car (I've never driven anything more than a stick-shift golf cart).

Comment: I assume that the facility is closed right now, but most of the time, they do have a couple of cars you can rent that are basically go-carts with seats in them.  I mean, they're not going to let you drive your own car on the track if you've never driven anything more than a go-cart, but they have cars that they let you drive that are definitely safer than a golf cart.

Comment: I'm not particularly interested in renting one of their cars. I just want to learn how to drive my own car.

Comment: Then you're going to have to find a place that lets you drive on a track with your own car.  There are a few places around that will let you do that, but I don't know of any that will let you do that for a couple of hours.  They're probably going to get you for a whole day's worth of time.  At that point, you might as well just rent one of their cars for the day.  It's a lot cheaper than the price of a new car.

Answer: I'm not sure if you can ride with someone else, but you can rent a car and get a professional driver to drive the car for you and teach you how to drive.

There are a few companies that can do this for you. I've heard good things about http://www.exoticdriving.com/

Answer: Maybe you could find a track day that a local car club is hosting. They usually are pretty affordable.

1) Hethel. They have a 'pro track' and a 'pro circuit' - both of which are open to the public.

http://www.hethel.com/racing-experiences/

2) Bedford Autodrome. They have a track (2.1 miles) that is available for public hire.

http://www.bedfordautodrome.co.uk/track-hire.html

Comment: @SethJ: I'm sure there are equivalents in every country.

Comment: I'm sure that there are a few in the US as well - although I'm not sure if they're open to the public.

Answer: The closest to your question I can think of is http://www.mrspeed.com/

Answer: I don't know about the UK, but in the US you can find out about your local track (if there is one) by calling the SCCA office near you. They will know who is operating the track, and they may even be able to give you the contact information for the track operator.

The SCCA website is a good place to start: http://www.scca.com/index.cfm

And if you find out there isn't a track near you, you could always become an SCCA member and start your own track. That's what I did!

prompt: My grandmother passed away and left her house to me and my father.. my dad sold the house and kept all the money. Is there anything I can do?
response_list:
It is impossible to answer your question without knowing the laws in your jurisdiction. In most jurisdictions, you can go to court and sue your father, but you will need a lawyer.

Comment: Can I sue my father?

If your dad sold the house and kept the money, then you're out of luck.

Comment: If my dad sells the house and keeps the money, will he have to report the sale on his tax return? And if so, will I (the beneficiary) have to report the sale on my tax return?

Comment: @user1612479 IANAL, so I don't know for sure. In general, however, the sale of an inherited house is a taxable event - that is, you'd have to report the sale.

Comment: @user1612479: Your father's tax return won't be affected, but you will have to report the sale on your tax return.

Not much.  If you didn't get the house, you don't get the money.  Did you have any claim on it, because your grandmother was your grandmother, or because you were named in a will?

Comment: No, I was named in a will.

Comment: So then you got what your grandmother left you.  If you expect anything more, you need to talk to a probate lawyer.

Comment: I'm really confused. I thought we were going to get the house and money?

Comment: @user11925, unless you and your father were named as co-owners in the will, you would have gotten only the house.  The money would have gone to your father.  The will did not name you as a co-owner?  What did it say?

Comment: @user11925, your dad may have inherited your grandmother's house and sold it, then inherited your grandmother's money, and is keeping it.

Comment: @user11925, if I understand you correctly, your grandmother left all her possessions to your father.  The house and the money were her possessions.  Your father sold the house and kept the money.  That's what your father did with the house and money that your grandmother left to him.  If there was anything wrong with that, it should have been brought up at the time.

Comment: In my state, if my grandmother left me her house, and it was valued at 200,000, I would get 100,000. My dad sold the house and kept the money, and I got nothing. I thought I was going to get 100,000.

Comment: @user11925, are you saying that your grandmother left half of her possessions to your father, and half to you?  If so, then your dad didn't break any rules.

Comment: My grandmother left half the house to me and half to my dad. She also left me all the money in her bank account. He sold the house, kept the money, and never gave me anything.

Comment: @user11925, did she leave you a specific amount of money?  Or did she leave you all her money?  If it was all her money, then it was up to your father to decide how to divide it.  It seems he chose to keep it all.  Was there any agreement between your father and you that you would get half of her estate?  If not, you're out of luck.

Comment: No, she left me all of her money. My dad still has the money that I was supposed to get.

Comment: @user11925, so it was all her money.  Not half of it.  You're out of luck.  You got what you got.

Comment: What if I didn't agree with him taking my money?

Comment: @ user11925, what are you asking?  The money was your grandmother's money.  She left it to your father.  Your father decided to keep all of it.  He had the right to do that.  If he'd given you half of it, you would have gotten half of it.  He didn't do that.  Your father had the right to do that.  If he didn't give you anything, there's nothing you can do about it.  If you want the half you didn't get, you're going to have to get a lawyer and sue your father.

Comment: Is there anything I can do?

Comment: @user11925, you can sue your father.  You can expect your father to give you half the money.  You can expect your father to give you a house.  (You'd have to pay for the house.  You can't expect your father to give you the house and expect you to pay for it.)  You can expect your father to be upset with you for suing him.

Comment: I feel like he should give me half.

Comment: @user11925, you can sue him.  Or you can expect him to be upset with you for suing him.

Comment: I guess I'll just talk to him. Thanks for your help.

Yes, you can.  You can bring a suit against your father for the right to the money.

But that suit will be very difficult to win.  You will have to prove that your father intended to defraud you in the sale of the house.  It's not an easy standard to meet.

You could also bring a suit for the right to the property in the house, but that will be even harder to win.  You will have to prove that your father intended to defraud you in the sale of the house.  Again, it's not an easy standard to meet.

Comment: This is correct.  If he didn't intend to defraud you, then the "intent" element isn't there.  You'll have a hard time proving that he did intend to defraud you.  You'll need documents and testimony.

Answer: If your father has any assets in his name, you can go after them in court. If he has no assets, you can try to get a judgment against him, but it will be tough to collect on it.

It sounds like you think your father cheated you out of your inheritance. But unless you can prove that he intended to cheat you, you're probably out of luck. You might have a better chance if your grandmother put the house in a trust, and the trust was supposed to pass the house to you or your father, but your father sold it and kept the money for himself.

Comment: I am not sure if this is correct.  If he sold the house for less than the value of the house, the OP could sue for the loss in value.  But the question is whether the OP can prove that his father intentionally defrauded him.

No. The house is gone.

Comment: I would have said "yes" to "is there anything I could do?" but I would have said "no" to "is there anything I can do?"

Comment: I think that the question is "is there anything I can do"

Comment: @BKay: yes, I agree. "can" is the crucial word.

Comment: @BKay: the question as written seems to be asking about the past tense.  I've edited it to make it clearer.

Comment: I would have said "is there anything I should do?"

Comment: @sleske: I do too, but I'm not sure it makes sense in this context.

Comment: @sleske: "should" is the past tense of "shall".  "Shall" is now obsolete except in legal language.  "Should" is a good substitute for "shall".

Comment: @BKay  Why wouldn't it make sense?  My grandmother passed away and left me her house.  I should have talked to her before the house was sold.

Answer: There is nothing you can do.  You are not a victim here.  You were an heir to your grandmother's estate.  The legal relationship between you and your grandmother is determined by the will.  In a will, the person making the will (Grandma in this case) is called the testator.  The person who is getting the benefits of the will (usually all the beneficiaries) is called the beneficiary.

You are a beneficiary.  Your father is not.  If you don't like the will, you can challenge it based on one of a few grounds.  If you were not told there was a will, you could challenge it for undue influence.  If there was no will, then you would inherit according to the laws of intestacy of your state.  If your grandmother had no will, then you would inherit the house because you would be considered the next of kin.

So the bottom line is, you have no recourse.

Comment: In California, you can't challenge the will for undue influence.

Comment: @Charles: that is correct.  There are only three grounds for a will contest.  Undue influence is not one of the three grounds.

Comment: @Charles: I was confused.  I thought you were in California.

Answer: \em{Is there anything I can do?}

If you can prove that your father was incompetent, you can file a lawsuit to set aside the sale of the house, and to put the house back in your father's name.

But if your father was perfectly competent, he can do whatever he wants with the house.

Answer: If your grandmother left her house to you and your father (and you), then you and your father are the beneficiaries of the estate.  If your father sold the house and kept all the money for himself, that is perfectly legal.  (I assume he has power of attorney to act for you as well?)

If you did not consent to the sale, then you can file a lawsuit against your father for the money.  But unless he did something criminal, you won't get it.

prompt: How do remote tribes that have no new genetic material for thousands of years not die out because of inbreeding?
response_list:
From [here](http://evolution.berkeley.edu/evolibrary/article/evo_7):

\begin{blockquote}

But the human population has not been isolated for 50,000 years. After
  the last ice age, humans spread across the globe. Genetic studies
  suggest that the migration out of Africa went through a bottleneck
  about 60,000 years ago. The population of humans dropped sharply, but
  eventually recovered. One theory for this bottleneck is that it was
  caused by a volcanic eruption in the North Pacific that created
  environmental changes that caused the human population to decrease
  to a few thousand individuals.
\end{blockquote}

So, in short, no, there are no human tribes that have had no new genetic material for thousands of years, unless they somehow managed to avoid the bottleneck.

Comment: Well, there are tribes that have had no new genetic material for a couple thousand years, but not for thousands of years.

Comment: @Kevin: So, what's the difference between "no new genetic material for a couple thousand years" and "no new genetic material for thousands of years"?

Comment: @Lagerbaer: The difference is 2000 years.

Comment: @Kevin: And? What's the difference between 0 and 2000?

Comment: @Lagerbaer: The difference between a couple thousand years and thousands of years is thousands of years.

Comment: @Lagerbaer: 2000 years is a little bit more than 2000 years.

Comment: @Kevin: So, I'm guessing the difference is that there are no human tribes that have had no new genetic material for thousands of years, unless they somehow managed to avoid the bottleneck.

Comment: @Lagerbaer: Yes. That would make a great answer.

Comment: @Lagerbaer: Thank you. I have upvoted and accepted your answer.

There is no absolute rule that all people must die out because of inbreeding.

The effects of inbreeding are not limited to the fertility of a population, but include other traits. For example, the offspring of related individuals might be more susceptible to certain diseases, or less intelligent. Individuals who reproduce more than their relatives might survive better, and the genetic diversity of the population might increase as a result.

So, it is possible that some individuals might survive better than their relatives. They might be better at avoiding predators, and thus more likely to reproduce and pass on their genes.

Of course, these effects might be limited. For example, if the tribe is very small, and everybody is related, it is less likely that there is a big variation in fitness. In this case, the tribe might die out if they are unable to adapt to their environment.

Comment: The inbreeding effects are not limited to fertility, but include other traits. For example, the offspring of related individuals might be more susceptible to certain diseases, or less intelligent. Individuals who reproduce more than their relatives might survive better, and the genetic diversity of the population might increase as a result.

Answer: There are two ways to address this.

First, consider that if there is a way to avoid inbreeding, inbreeding is not a problem. So if people don't die out, there's a way to avoid it.

Second, if we assume that there is a way to avoid inbreeding, there are \em{many} ways to avoid inbreeding. So the tribe can simply find one of those ways.

E.g., 1000 years ago, if all of the people from your tribe wanted to marry someone from the neighbouring tribe, they wouldn't be able to do so. That's because there is not enough space to fit both tribes. But if one of the tribes dies out, then the other tribe can grow.

So if you want to know how to avoid inbreeding, you have to choose one of the many ways to avoid inbreeding.

Comment: Thanks, I didn't know there were so many ways to avoid inbreeding.

They marry their cousins.

Comment: Please look up the term "inbreeding".

Comment: @SidharthBhatia: I think that if you look up "cousins" on the same page, you'll find out that they're not the same thing.

Comment: @SidharthBhatia: I wonder what your objection is.  You know that people marry their *first* cousins; in fact, in the US you can't even marry your *second* cousins.  How on earth does that make "inbreeding" a silly term?

Comment: @Charles: I don't think that's the case.

Comment: @SidharthBhatia: Sure it is.  You can marry your first cousin in many states; you can't marry your second cousin in any state.

Comment: @Charles: I'm not sure if it's the case in all states. I'll check.

Comment: @SidharthBhatia: That's what I understand to be the case.  I'd love to hear that it isn't, though.

Comment: @Charles: You're right. It is the case in all states.

Comment: @SidharthBhatia: That's what I thought.  :-)

Answer: Most of the time, even if the tribe is small, they won't be inbreeding, because the tribe isn't closed.  They don't all live together in one village.  The tribe usually covers an area of several square kilometers, and the various villages are hundreds of kilometers apart.  They trade, travel, and communicate with the other villages.

Comment: I've edited the question to reflect this.

Comment: I've downvoted this answer because you're wrong.

Answer: I think that you're mistaken on the definition of "inbreeding".  The term is used to describe the mating of close relatives.  "Inbreeding" doesn't mean "not marrying outside the tribe", it means "marrying someone who is closely related by blood".  You can do the former without doing the latter.  It's quite possible that tribes like the ones you describe have a long history of marrying cousins, but that doesn't necessarily mean that they're all related to each other.

Answer: It's not a problem, particularly if there is an extended family structure.  In a society where, for example, all the males of a clan are brothers, brothers often marry sisters.  This allows the clan to retain a good deal of its genetic diversity.

Answer: I'm sure that this is a well-understood phenomenon, but I'm not sure what the answer is.  I think that, in general, it would be very easy for them to die out.  However, by your own description, they don't; they thrive.

To answer your question, it seems to me that the most likely answer is that there are a relatively small number of these "tribes," and they are all interconnected by trade and intermarriage.  This way, when a tribe dies out, they can be replaced by a new tribe from one of the others.  So, in the long run, the population of tribes stays fairly constant.

For example, suppose that there are one thousand such tribes.  Each tribe dies out every 200 years, on average.  This means that the population of tribes is replaced once every 1,000 years (i.e., on average, one new tribe will be formed every year).  So, these tribes won't die out.  They might become less numerous, and there might be less genetic diversity, but neither of those things would be enough to kill the tribes off.  The genetic diversity is reduced because the tribes are, on average, half the size that they would be if they were completely unrelated.  But, a reduction in genetic diversity by a factor of two is not enough to make the tribes die off, so there must be a lot more tribes than that.
