Answer: I think your question is actually twofold:
\begin{itemize}
\item What should I look for when buying a car?
\item How should I go about haggling with the dealer?
\end{itemize}

\strong{Car Buying}

Don't buy the first car you see. Look around and find the make and model you want. Compare the features and options between different makes and models, and make sure you get the car that's best for you.

Don't buy the first car you see from a single dealer. Check out several car lots, and compare prices.

\strong{Haggling}

Don't bother with the "no haggling" deals. They're a ripoff.

Don't buy the first car you see from a single dealer. Check out several car lots, and compare prices.

Don't be afraid to walk away. The car will still be there tomorrow. If they won't haggle with you on price, then they're not a good dealer.

\em{It depends.}

If you buy a new car from a dealer or a private party, you should get a [Carfax report](http://www.carfax.com/) to see if the car has been in an accident.

If you buy a car from a dealer, you have a "lemon law" that protects you against fraud.  It may vary by state, but basically if you buy a defective car that is not repairable, you can return it for a refund.

The biggest risk of buying a used car is getting screwed.  If you are buying from a dealer, you should be protected, but private sales are a different matter.  You have no protection if you go into a deal with someone you don't know at all, and they could just take your money and drive away.

If you are going to be upside down on the loan, you will have to make up the difference when you trade it in.  Also, when the car breaks, you will be upside down and not be able to afford the repairs.  So you may not want to buy a car that is more expensive than you can afford.

prompt: I reported a supervisor for sexual harassment. He got fired. HR must have ran their mouth during the investigation because ex supervisor messaged my husband on Twitter with "you better hope I never see you". What steps should I take now?
response_list:
I am not a lawyer but I will answer with a lawyer's perspective.

You should tell your boss (if you have one) about the message. Ask him/her if he/she knows anything about it. If you have friends in the company, you can ask them to talk to the ex-supervisor and try to find out what's going on.

If you believe the ex-supervisor is trying to intimidate you, you can file a complaint with HR, and in some cases, with the police.

There are two issues here - the first is that you are not sure if your complaint was considered a retaliation complaint or not.

When you file a formal complaint about sexual harassment, the employer is required to investigate the complaint and take action in response to the results of the investigation.  (This is required under federal law - Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, 42 U.S.C. § 2000e-2(m).)  As part of the investigation, the employer should interview witnesses and review evidence to try to determine whether sexual harassment was occurring.  If the investigation concludes that harassment was occurring, the employer must take action to stop it.

So it is likely that the employer was required to investigate your complaint about the supervisor, and that the investigator would have had to interview you as part of that process.  That is, in itself, not retaliation, and is a normal part of an investigation.

The second issue is whether the employer retaliated against you for filing the complaint.  Under federal law, an employer may not retaliate against an employee for filing a complaint.  If the investigation was conducted in a biased manner, or if the employer took adverse action against you (firing, demotion, reduction in hours, etc.) because you filed the complaint, that would be retaliation.

If you believe that you have been retaliated against, you should speak with an employment lawyer who can help you determine the appropriate action to take, and, if necessary, file a lawsuit against the employer.

Comment: This is a good answer and I would also recommend finding out the exact reason for the supervisor being fired. If it's because of the complaint, then the retaliation is likely done through the HR department. If the supervisor was fired for other reasons that are unrelated to the complaint, then the retaliation may be coming from them directly.

It is illegal for him to contact you directly, but it is legal for him to contact your husband.  The best thing to do is to not interact with him and not communicate with him.  If he continues to contact you, you may need to involve your company's HR department or the police.

First, I would suggest that you tell your husband to ignore the message. You have no idea if the supervisor was serious or just blowing off some steam.

Second, I suggest that you contact the EEOC and report the supervisor. It is not clear from your question if you worked for the city or a private company. If you worked for the city, the EEOC will forward your complaint to the city. If you worked for a private company, the EEOC will open an investigation. (You could also call your city attorney's office and have them file a complaint on your behalf.)

Third, I suggest that you contact your lawyer and tell him what the supervisor did. Your lawyer can give you advice about what to do next.

Answer: The ex-supervisor's message is clearly a threat that could be prosecuted as a crime. If you are in the United States, file a police report. If you are not, file a police report in whatever country you are in and contact a local lawyer to determine whether there is a legal remedy for you. The threat could be prosecuted as a criminal offense in the US, and it is probably criminal behavior in other countries too.

Comment: I suggest the OP contact a lawyer before filing a police report. Although the ex-supervisor's message suggests that he intends to personally harm the OP, the OP should be cautious about making an accusation that could be seen as a false accusation. It's better to have a lawyer advise the OP about how to proceed.

Comment: @NickC That's a very good point. I'll edit my answer to reflect this.

It is entirely possible that the supervisor was fired for reasons not related to the complaint you filed.  For example, he may have been fired for insubordination or for misconduct.  Unless you are privy to the actual reasons the supervisor was fired, you cannot assume that it was because of the complaint you filed against him.

That being said, if you are concerned about this, you may consider filing a complaint with the EEO.  If you do so, you should consider consulting with an employment lawyer before you file.
